summary_llm:
The play opens on Christmas Eve in the comfortably furnished home of Nora and Torvald Helmer. Nora, in high spirits, returns from shopping, hiding macaroons from her husband, Torvald. Torvald, a newly appointed bank manager, playfully scolds Nora for being a "spendthrift" and reminds her of his strict policy against debt and borrowing. Nora, however, is excited about their improved financial situation after the New Year, when Torvald's new salary begins. She reveals she has been buying Christmas presents for their three children and the maids, and hints at a secret gift for Torvald.

Their conversation is interrupted by the arrival of Mrs. Linde, an old school friend of Nora's, whom Nora hasn't seen in many years. Mrs. Linde is a widow, having lost her husband three years prior, and has no children. She explains she has had a hard life, working constantly to support her bedridden mother and two younger brothers, but now that they are self-sufficient, she feels "unspeakably empty" and is looking for work in town, preferably office work.

Nora, delighted by her husband's new position, promises to speak to Torvald about finding Mrs. Linde a job at the bank. She then confides a "great secret" to Mrs. Linde: when Torvald was gravely ill early in their marriage, doctors advised a year in Italy to save his life. To fund this, Nora secretly borrowed two hundred and fifty pounds, leading Torvald and others to believe her dying father had provided the money. She has been diligently paying off the debt through small, secret earnings from needlework and copying, and by saving half of her household allowance, often at personal sacrifice. She expresses pride in having saved Torvald's life and managing the debt.

Shortly after, a lawyer named Krogstad arrives to see Torvald on bank business. Mrs. Linde recognizes him and is visibly disturbed. Dr. Rank, a close family friend and frequent visitor, also emerges from Torvald's study, revealing Krogstad is "morally diseased" and is currently with Helmer. Nora offers Dr. Rank a macaroon, admitting they are forbidden by Torvald. She also jokes about wanting to say "I'm damned!" if Torvald could hear her.

When Torvald appears, Nora introduces Mrs. Linde and immediately begins to lobby him for a position for her friend at the bank. Torvald agrees to consider it. After Torvald, Dr. Rank, and Mrs. Linde depart, Krogstad reappears. He confronts Nora, revealing that Torvald is dismissing him from his post at the bank and giving it to Mrs. Linde. Krogstad demands Nora use her influence to ensure he keeps his job, threatening to expose her secret if she fails. He reveals he knows she forged her father's signature on the bond for the loan, pointing out that the signature is dated three days after her father's death and the date is in Nora's handwriting. Nora confesses to the forgery, explaining she did it to save Torvald's life and couldn't burden her dying father with the truth of Torvald's illness. Krogstad warns her that the law cares nothing for motives and that his own past "indiscretion" (which cost him his reputation) was no worse than hers. He states that if he loses his position, she will lose hers with him.

Nora is terrified. When Torvald returns, she tries to distract him from checking the letterbox, where Krogstad's letter is. She attempts to persuade Torvald to keep Krogstad, but Torvald refuses, citing Krogstad's moral failings (forgery) and, more importantly, his overly familiar manner towards him. He believes Krogstad's presence would make his position at the bank intolerable and that a deceitful person poisons a home, especially affecting children. Torvald sends off Krogstad's dismissal letter. Nora is distraught, realizing it's too late, but Torvald assures her he will protect her and take all responsibility if anything comes to light.

In Act II, Nora is visibly anxious. The Christmas tree is stripped of its decorations. She checks the letterbox, finding it empty. She discusses with the Nurse the possibility of children forgetting their mother if she leaves. Mrs. Linde arrives to help Nora mend her Tarantella dress for the upcoming fancy-dress ball. Nora reveals Dr. Rank is suffering from a terminal spinal disease, inherited from his father's excesses. Mrs. Linde, suspecting Dr. Rank lent Nora the money, advises Nora to end her relationship with him. Nora denies Dr. Rank's involvement but admits she needs to "make an end of it" with Krogstad. Mrs. Linde senses Nora is hiding something serious.

When Torvald comes home, Nora desperately tries to prevent him from checking the letterbox by asking him to help her practice her Tarantella dance. During the practice, Nora dances wildly, seemingly possessed by anxiety. Dr. Rank plays the piano, and Mrs. Linde observes. Helmer is concerned by Nora's intensity and agrees to coach her, promising not to open any letters or the letterbox until after the ball. After Helmer and Dr. Rank leave for dinner, Mrs. Linde reveals she went to see Krogstad but he was out of town; she left him a note. Nora, overwhelmed, calculates she has only "thirty-one hours to live" until the secret is revealed.

Act III begins with Mrs. Linde waiting for Krogstad. When he arrives, she reveals she asked him to meet her. She confesses she left him years ago for a wealthier man to support her family, but now that her obligations are fulfilled, she feels her life is empty. She proposes they reunite and work together, offering to be a mother to his children. Krogstad is overjoyed and accepts, seeing a chance to redeem his reputation. Mrs. Linde then tells Krogstad that his letter to Helmer is already in the letterbox. Krogstad wants to retrieve it, but Mrs. Linde insists Helmer must read it, believing that the "unhappy secret must be disclosed" for Nora and Helmer to achieve a "complete understanding." Krogstad agrees to this, stating he will wait for her downstairs.

Helmer and Nora return from the ball, with Helmer playfully chastising Nora for wanting to stay longer. He expresses his possessive affection for her. Dr. Rank then arrives, revealing he has received "absolute certainty" about his terminal illness and will soon "lie rotting in the churchyard." He tells them he will send a card with a black cross when the end is near, signifying his final farewell. He asks Helmer for a cigar, and Nora lights it for him. He then states he will be "invisible" at the next ball, implying his death. He leaves.

Helmer goes to empty the letterbox, noticing someone tried to pick the lock (Nora's attempt). He finds Dr. Rank's cards with black crosses and Krogstad's letter. Nora tries to stop him, but Helmer reads the letter. He is horrified, calling Nora a "hypocrite, a liar—worse, worse—a criminal!" He blames her father's lack of principle and fears his own reputation will be ruined, believing people will suspect him of complicity. He declares their marriage over, stating she will remain in the house only for appearances, and he will not allow her to raise the children.

Just then, the maid brings another letter for Nora. Helmer takes it and reads it. He shouts with joy, announcing he is "saved!" Krogstad, having found happiness with Mrs. Linde, has returned Nora's bond and expressed regret. Helmer tears up the bond and both letters, throwing them into the stove. He then "forgives" Nora, believing she acted out of love but lacked understanding. He promises to protect her, calling her his "frightened little singing-bird" and "helpless darling," and states that she has become "both wife and child to him."

Nora, however, has changed into her everyday dress. She tells Helmer they must have a serious conversation, the first in their eight years of marriage. She states that neither her father nor Helmer ever truly loved her, but only enjoyed being "in love" with her. She feels she has been a "doll-child" to her father and a "doll-wife" to Helmer, living in a "playroom." She declares she is not fit to raise the children and must educate herself, announcing she is leaving him and their home immediately.

Helmer is shocked and forbids her, but Nora asserts he can no longer forbid her anything. She explains she needs to stand alone to understand herself and her place in the world. Helmer appeals to her "sacred duties" as a wife and mother, but Nora counters that she has "other duties just as sacred" to herself. She questions the fairness of laws that prevent a woman from saving her dying father or husband. Helmer believes she is ill or out of her mind, but Nora insists her mind has never been clearer. She tells him she no longer loves him. She explains that the "wonderful thing" she had hoped for—that he would sacrifice his honor for her—did not happen. Instead, he only cared about his own reputation, revealing to her that she had been living with a "strange man" for eight years.

Helmer offers to change, suggesting they live like "brother and sister," but Nora says it's too late. She returns her wedding ring and demands his, declaring she is setting them both free from all obligations. She refuses any further contact or help from him. Nora states that for their life together to be a "real wedlock," both of them would have to be "so changed," but she no longer believes in "wonderful things happening." She leaves the house, and the sound of a door shutting is heard from below. Helmer is left alone, calling her name, then questions if "The most wonderful thing of all—?" might still happen.

Alice, bored while sitting by her sister on a riverbank, notices a White Rabbit with pink eyes, wearing a waistcoat, taking a watch from its pocket and exclaiming, "Oh dear! Oh dear! I shall be late!" Driven by curiosity, Alice follows the Rabbit down a large rabbit-hole.

She falls for a long time down a deep well, passing cupboards, bookshelves, maps, and pictures. She takes an empty jar of "ORANGE MARMALADE" and places it in a cupboard as she continues to fall. During her descent, she contemplates her location, her cat Dinah, and eventually dozes off, dreaming of Dinah. She suddenly lands on a pile of sticks and dry leaves, unhurt.

Alice sees the White Rabbit hurrying down a long passage, lamenting his lateness. She follows him into a long, low hall lined with locked doors. On a small glass table, she finds a tiny golden key. The key is too small for the large doors, but she discovers a low curtain concealing a fifteen-inch-high door, which the golden key fits. Opening it, she sees a beautiful garden but is too large to enter.

Returning to the table, Alice finds a bottle labeled "DRINK ME." After ensuring it's not poison, she drinks the contents, which taste like a mixture of various foods. She immediately begins to shrink, becoming ten inches tall, the perfect size for the small door. However, she realizes she left the golden key on the table, now far out of her reach. She tries to climb the table leg but fails, then sits down and cries, creating a pool of tears.

Scolding herself, Alice soon notices a small cake under the table marked "EAT ME." She eats it, hoping it will change her size. Instead of shrinking, she grows enormously, becoming over nine feet tall, her head hitting the hall's roof. She grabs the key and rushes to the garden door, but is now too big to get through, only able to peer in with one eye. She sits down and cries again, adding to the pool of tears she created earlier, which now fills half the hall.

The White Rabbit returns, splendidly dressed, carrying gloves and a fan, muttering about the Duchess. Alice, desperate, asks for help, startling the Rabbit, who drops his items and flees. Alice picks up the fan and gloves. As she fans herself, she begins to shrink again, realizing the fan is the cause. She quickly drops it to avoid disappearing entirely, ending up about two feet tall. She runs back to the small door, but it's locked, and the key is still on the unreachable table.

Her foot slips, and she falls into the pool of tears, now chin-deep in salt water. She swims, regretting her excessive crying. She encounters a Mouse also swimming in the pool. Alice attempts to speak to it, first in English, then in French, which frightens the Mouse. Alice apologizes, realizing the Mouse dislikes cats. She tries to soothe it by describing her own cat, Dinah, but inadvertently mentions Dinah's mouse-catching skills, further offending the Mouse. She then mentions a dog that kills rats, causing the Mouse to swim away in disgust. Alice calls it back, promising not to mention cats or dogs. The Mouse agrees to tell its story on the shore.

The pool has become crowded with other creatures (a Duck, a Dodo, a Lory, an Eaglet), and Alice leads them all to the bank. They are all dripping wet and uncomfortable. They discuss how to get dry. The Mouse attempts to dry them by reciting a dry history lesson about William the Conqueror, but it's ineffective. The Dodo proposes a "Caucus-race," which involves running in a circle, starting and stopping whenever one likes, until everyone is dry. After about half an hour, the Dodo declares everyone has won and must have prizes. Alice, designated as the prize-giver, distributes comfits from her pocket to everyone. For her own prize, she offers a thimble, which the Dodo solemnly presents back to her.

After the prizes, the Mouse begins its promised "long and a sad tale," which Alice initially misunderstands as a "long tail." The Mouse recites a poem about a trial between Fury and a mouse, where the mouse is condemned to death. Alice's inattention and comments about the "fifth bend" (mishearing "end") offend the Mouse, who walks away. Alice, trying to win it back, mentions her cat Dinah's prowess at catching mice and birds, which causes all the birds to flee in terror. Alice is left alone and cries again.

The White Rabbit reappears, searching for his lost fan and gloves, muttering about the Duchess. He mistakes Alice for his housemaid, Mary Ann, and orders her to fetch them from his house. Alice, frightened, obeys, finding the Rabbit's house and going upstairs. She finds a fan and gloves, along with another bottle. She drinks from it, hoping to grow, and does so rapidly, filling the entire room. Her head presses against the ceiling, one arm extends out the window, and one foot up the chimney.

The Rabbit returns, calling for Mary Ann. Alice's elbow prevents him from opening the door. He tries the window, and Alice, with her hand, snatches at him, causing a shriek and broken glass. The Rabbit then calls for "Pat" (a Lizard named Bill), ordering him to remove Alice's arm from the window. Alice snatches again, causing more shrieks and broken glass. She hears the creatures outside planning to use ladders and send Bill the Lizard down the chimney. Alice kicks her foot down the chimney, sending Bill flying out. The Rabbit suggests burning the house down, but Alice threatens to set Dinah on them. They then throw pebbles, which turn into little cakes, into the window. Alice eats one, shrinks, and runs out of the house, escaping the crowd of animals.

In the wood, Alice plans to grow to her normal size and find the garden. She encounters an enormous puppy and, after a brief, terrifying game of fetch, escapes. She finds a large mushroom and a blue Caterpillar sitting on top, smoking a hookah. The Caterpillar asks Alice, "Who are _you?_" Alice explains her identity crisis due to constant size changes. The Caterpillar is unimpressed and asks her to recite "You are old, Father William," which Alice does incorrectly. The Caterpillar criticizes her recitation. When Alice expresses a desire to be a "little larger" than three inches, the Caterpillar (who is exactly three inches tall) becomes angry. It then crawls away, telling Alice that one side of the mushroom will make her grow taller and the other shorter.

Alice breaks off a piece from each side of the mushroom. She nibbles the right-hand bit and shrinks until her chin hits her foot. She then eats from the left-hand bit, and her neck grows immensely long, like a serpent, rising above the treetops. A Pigeon attacks her, mistaking her for a serpent trying to steal its eggs. Alice tries to explain she is a little girl, but the Pigeon doesn't believe her. Alice eventually manages to eat from both pieces of mushroom, returning herself to her normal height. She then sees a small house and, to avoid frightening its inhabitants, shrinks herself to nine inches tall before approaching.

At the house, Alice observes a Fish-Footman delivering a croquet invitation from the Queen to a Frog-Footman for the Duchess. She enters the house and finds the Duchess nursing a sneezing, howling baby in a smoky kitchen, while a Cook throws dishes and fire-irons around. A Cheshire Cat sits by the fire, grinning. Alice asks about the Cat's grin, and the Duchess explains it's a "Cheshire cat." The Duchess then sings a violent lullaby to the baby, shaking it severely. She flings the baby at Alice, saying she must go play croquet with the Queen. Alice takes the squirming baby outside, where she realizes it is transforming into a pig. She sets it down, and it trots away into the wood.

Alice then sees the Cheshire Cat again, sitting on a tree branch. She asks it which way to go. The Cat explains that it depends on where she wants to get to, and since she doesn't care, it doesn't matter. It tells her that a Hatter and a March Hare live nearby, and both are mad. The Cat explains that everyone here is mad, including Alice, because she came. It demonstrates its own madness by growling when pleased and wagging its tail when angry. The Cat vanishes and reappears several times, finally disappearing slowly, leaving only its grin floating in the air for a while.

Alice finds the March Hare's house, where the March Hare and the Hatter are having a never-ending tea-party with a sleeping Dormouse. They tell Alice there's "no room," but she sits down. They offer her wine, but there is none, leading to an argument about civility. The Hatter asks the riddle "Why is a raven like a writing-desk?" but neither he nor the March Hare knows the answer. The Hatter explains that he and "Time" had a quarrel, so it's always six o'clock (tea-time), which is why they constantly move around the table for clean cups. The Dormouse, after being pinched awake, tells a nonsensical story about three sisters living in a "treacle-well" and drawing "treacle" and things beginning with "M." Alice, frustrated by their rudeness and illogic, leaves the party.

She finds a door in a tree, which leads her back to the long hall. She retrieves the golden key, uses her mushroom to shrink to a foot high, and finally enters the beautiful garden. She sees three card-shaped gardeners painting white roses red to avoid the Queen's wrath, as they mistakenly planted a white rose-tree. The Queen's procession arrives, consisting of card-soldiers, courtiers, royal children, guests (including the White Rabbit), the Knave of Hearts, and finally, the King and Queen of Hearts. Alice refuses to lie down like the gardeners. The Queen asks Alice her name and who the gardeners are. Alice, feeling brave, says she doesn't know and it's "no business of mine." The furious Queen screams "Off with her head!" but Alice dismisses it as "Nonsense!" The King intervenes, and the Queen orders the gardeners' heads off. Alice hides the gardeners in a flower-pot.

The Queen invites Alice to play croquet. The game is chaotic: the ground is uneven, the balls are live hedgehogs, the mallets are live flamingoes, and the arches are doubled-up soldiers who constantly move. The Queen frequently shouts "Off with his head!" or "Off with her head!" Alice sees the Cheshire Cat's grin appear. She complains to the Cat about the unfair game. The King tries to have the Cat's head removed, but the executioner argues it's impossible without a body. Alice suggests asking the Duchess, who is in prison. As the executioner goes to fetch the Duchess, the Cat's head fades away.

The Duchess returns, linking arms with Alice, and begins a conversation filled with convoluted morals. The Queen reappears, angrily ordering the Duchess to leave or be beheaded. The Duchess vanishes instantly. The Queen sends Alice and the Gryphon to hear the Mock Turtle's story. The Gryphon reveals that the Queen's execution threats are never carried out. They find the Mock Turtle, who is weeping. He tells them he "was a real Turtle" and describes his education at a sea-school, including subjects like "Reeling and Writhing" and "Uglification." He also describes a dance called the "Lobster Quadrille," which he and the Gryphon demonstrate, singing a song about a whiting and a snail. Alice tries to recite a poem but gets the words wrong, further confusing the Mock Turtle and Gryphon.

Suddenly, a cry of "The trial's beginning!" is heard. The Gryphon pulls Alice away, and they run to the court. The King and Queen of Hearts are on their throne, with the Knave of Hearts in chains, accused of stealing the Queen's tarts. The White Rabbit acts as herald. Alice observes the King as judge and twelve animal-jurors writing on slates. The White Rabbit reads the accusation: a poem stating the Knave stole the tarts.

The Hatter is called as the first witness, providing confusing testimony about his tea-party. Alice grows larger again, causing discomfort to the Dormouse. The King threatens the Hatter with execution for his unclear evidence. A guinea-pig cheers and is suppressed by being stuffed into a bag. The Hatter is dismissed, and the Queen orders his head off, but he escapes. The Duchess's Cook is the next witness, refusing to give evidence and only saying tarts are made of "Pepper, mostly." The Dormouse interjects "Treacle," leading to chaos as the Queen orders its beheading and suppression. During the commotion, the Cook disappears.

Finally, the White Rabbit calls the last witness: Alice. Alice, forgetting her size, jumps up and knocks over the jury-box, spilling the jurymen. She hastily puts them back, correcting Bill the Lizard who was placed upside down. The King asks Alice what she knows about the stolen tarts, and she replies, "Nothing." The King declares this "very important," but the White Rabbit corrects him to "unimportant." The King then reads "Rule Forty-two: _All persons more than a mile high to leave the court_." Alice, now very large, refuses to leave, arguing the rule was just invented. The King, flustered, tells the jury to consider their verdict.

The White Rabbit then produces a newly found paper, a set of verses, which he claims is a letter from the prisoner. The Knave denies writing it. The King insists not signing it proves guilt. Alice argues the verses prove nothing as they are nonsensical. The White Rabbit reads the verses, which are indeed obscure. The King attempts to interpret them, trying to link lines to the Knave and Queen. The Queen, enraged by a pun, shouts "Sentence first—verdict afterwards!" Alice, now at her full size, loudly declares, "Stuff and nonsense! Who cares for you? You're nothing but a pack of cards!"

At this, the entire pack of cards flies up and descends upon Alice. She screams and tries to bat them away, only to find herself lying on the riverbank, with her head in her sister's lap. Her sister wakes her, asking about her long sleep. Alice recounts her "curious dream" to her sister. Her sister, after listening, kisses her and sends her off for tea. Alice runs, marveling at her wonderful dream. Her sister remains on the bank, contemplating Alice's adventures, and begins to dream herself, imagining the characters and events of Wonderland, and how they would transform back into the ordinary sounds and sights of her own world. She then pictures Alice as a grown woman, sharing these tales with future children, retaining her childhood heart and joy.

The plot of the provided text, "Anna Karenina," unfolds across eight parts, detailing the intertwined lives and relationships of several prominent Russian families, primarily the Oblonskys, Karenins, Shtcherbatskys, and Levin.

**Part One** begins with the Oblonsky family in disarray. Darya Alexandrovna (Dolly) has discovered her husband, Prince Stepan Arkadyevitch Oblonsky (Stiva), is having an affair with their French governess. This revelation has caused three days of turmoil, with Dolly refusing to leave her room and Stiva sleeping in his study. Stiva, a charming but self-indulgent man, feels remorse for being caught but not for the affair itself. He recalls his "idiotic smile" that enraged Dolly. Their household staff is affected, with some giving notice. Stiva's valet, Matvey, hints at Stiva's financial difficulties and suggests that Stiva's sister, Anna Arkadyevna, might help reconcile the couple. Dolly, however, announces her intention to leave. Stiva attempts to reconcile with Dolly, expressing regret and mentioning their children, but Dolly is furious, calling him "loathsome" and a "stranger." She threatens to expose him. A child's cry briefly softens her, but she ultimately slams the door on him. Stiva leaves for his office, while Dolly, despite her anger, is consumed by household duties and the impossibility of leaving with her five children.

At his office, Stiva, a well-connected and respected government official, is visited by his old friend, Konstantin Dmitrievitch Levin. Levin, a country gentleman, is shy and feels out of place in Moscow. He has come to propose to Kitty Shtcherbatskaya, Dolly's younger sister, with whom he has been in love since his youth. Levin had previously left Moscow, convinced he was unworthy of Kitty due to his unconventional life, but has returned determined to propose. He is annoyed by his half-brother, Sergey Ivanovitch Koznishev, being mentioned. Levin expresses his disillusionment with local government, having resigned from the district council. Stiva, aware of Levin's feelings for Kitty, suggests he visit the Zoological Gardens where Kitty skates.

Levin, heart pounding, finds Kitty at the skating rink. He is overwhelmed by her presence but forces himself to speak to her. They skate together, and Levin, in a moment of emotion, tells her his stay depends on her. Kitty, remembering Vronsky, skates away. The old Prince Shtcherbatsky and Princess Shtcherbatskaya arrive. The Princess, who prefers Vronsky for Kitty, stiffly invites Levin to visit. Kitty, however, softens her mother's coldness by saying "Good-bye till this evening." Stiva arrives and takes Levin to dinner.

At the restaurant, Levin is uncomfortable with the city's artificiality. Stiva, guessing Levin's intentions, encourages him, saying Dolly believes Kitty will marry him. Levin is overjoyed but then stung by Stiva's revelation that Count Alexey Kirillovitch Vronsky, a wealthy and charming officer, is also in love with Kitty and is a serious rival. Stiva, seeking advice on his own infidelity, describes his mistress and asks Levin how he can reconcile his love for his wife with his passion for another. Levin, disgusted, divides women into "women" and "vermin" and dismisses Stiva's "tragedy." Stiva argues that life is not "all of a piece." Levin leaves, still determined to propose.

Kitty, at home, is excited by the prospect of Vronsky's proposal. She recalls her tender feelings for Levin but sees a brilliant future with Vronsky. When Levin arrives early, she realizes he intends to propose and is horrified at having to hurt him. She tells him she cannot marry him. The Princess enters, relieved. Countess Nordston, a friend of Kitty's, teases Levin. Vronsky arrives, and Levin, seeing Kitty's bright eyes, knows she loves Vronsky. Levin observes Vronsky's "humble submission and dread" when he looks at Anna. The Prince, who prefers Levin, is cold to Vronsky. Levin leaves, his last impression being Kitty's happy face as she talks to Vronsky. Kitty, though glad to have received an offer, feels remorse for Levin. The Prince and Princess argue about Vronsky, with the Prince accusing his wife of "matchmaking" and ruining Kitty.

Vronsky, who has led a luxurious and coarse life, is charmed by Kitty's innocence but doesn't consider marriage. He feels a strong bond with her. He goes to meet his mother at the Petersburg railway station, where he encounters Stiva. Stiva tells him Levin proposed to Kitty and was rejected. Vronsky feels like a conqueror. He then sees Anna Karenina, Stiva's sister, and is immediately captivated by her "caressing and soft" expression. A station guard is crushed by a train, which Anna calls an "omen of evil." Vronsky gives money to the widow. Anna asks about Vronsky, and Stiva reveals he hopes Vronsky will marry Kitty.

Anna stays with Dolly, who is distraught over Stiva's affair. Anna, with genuine sympathy, helps Dolly and Stiva reconcile. Anna, however, feels a growing attraction to Vronsky. At a ball, she dances with Vronsky, and their mutual attraction is evident to all, including Kitty, who is devastated. Anna intentionally avoids Vronsky's bow, but her eyes betray her feelings. Anna leaves the ball early, feeling a mix of pleasure and dread. She realizes she is falling in love with Vronsky.

Back in Petersburg, Anna continues to meet Vronsky in society. She initially resists his advances but soon realizes his pursuit is the "whole interest of her life." Vronsky, in turn, finds his life with Anna fulfilling, but the secrecy and deceit begin to weigh on him. Anna becomes pregnant. She confesses this to Vronsky, who is initially pale and silent, but then declares they must end the deception and live together. Anna, however, is terrified of leaving her son, Seryozha. She dreams of her husband and Vronsky both being her husbands.

Alexey Alexandrovitch Karenin, Anna's husband, notices the societal whispers about Anna and Vronsky. He is not jealous by nature but feels his position is compromised. He decides to confront Anna, demanding she cease seeing Vronsky. He accuses her of being "base" and "immoral." Anna, in a fit of anger, confesses her love for Vronsky and her hatred for him. Alexey Alexandrovitch, though deeply wounded, resolves to maintain an "external _status quo_" to avoid scandal, but plans to punish her by taking Seryozha and seeking a divorce. He consults a lawyer, who suggests "adultery by mutual consent" for an easy divorce, but Alexey Alexandrovitch's religious scruples and desire to prevent Anna from being happy with Vronsky make him reject this.

Kitty, meanwhile, is sent to a German watering-place to recover from her illness, which her father believes is due to Vronsky's slight. She befriends Varenka, a kind and selfless Russian girl who cares for an invalid, Madame Stahl. Kitty is inspired by Varenka's spiritual life and philanthropic work, contrasting it with her own past worldly pursuits. She tries to emulate Varenka, but her father, Prince Shtcherbatsky, returns and punctures her idealized view of Madame Stahl and her new friends. Kitty is also distressed when she realizes a sick artist, Petrov, has developed feelings for her, causing awkwardness with his wife. Varenka confesses a past love affair that ended due to the man's mother. Kitty, relating this to her own situation, feels shame and humiliation. She realizes her "new life" was a "sham." She returns to Russia, cured but changed, her Moscow troubles a memory.

**Part Two** focuses on Levin's attempts to find meaning in life and his eventual marriage to Kitty. After his rejection by Kitty, Levin returns to his country estate, feeling disillusioned. He tries to implement new farming methods, but faces resistance from his peasants. He is also troubled by his dying brother, Nikolay, who is consumed by illness and bitterness. Nikolay, living with Marya Nikolaevna, rages against society and his brothers. Levin, witnessing Nikolay's suffering and his own fear of death, questions the meaning of life. He finds solace in hard physical labor, mowing with his peasants, and feels a connection to their simple, laborious life. He encounters Kitty again, and their love is rekindled.

Levin proposes to Kitty a second time, and she accepts. Their engagement and wedding are a mix of joy and awkwardness, as Levin struggles with religious ceremonies he doesn't fully believe in and his own past "sins." He confesses his past to Kitty, who, though deeply hurt by his lack of purity, forgives him. Their early married life is marked by unexpected quarrels and adjustments, but they find happiness in their shared life in the country.

**Part Three** details Anna and Vronsky's life abroad and Alexey Alexandrovitch's reaction. After Anna's confession and Vronsky's suicide attempt, Alexey Alexandrovitch, though initially filled with rage and a desire for divorce, is moved by Anna's near-death experience and forgives her. He feels a "spiritual peace" and even tenderness for the baby girl, who is Vronsky's child. However, he soon realizes his position is untenable in society. Countess Lidia Ivanovna, a pious friend, takes charge of Alexey Alexandrovitch's household and encourages his new-found religious fervor, which helps him cope with his humiliation.

Anna and Vronsky, meanwhile, are living in Italy. Vronsky, initially happy, soon experiences _ennui_ and takes up painting. He commissions a portrait of Anna from a Russian artist, Mihailov, who captures Anna's beauty but also her inner turmoil. Vronsky's own attempts at painting are less successful. Anna, though happy with Vronsky, struggles with her separation from Seryozha and the social ostracism they face. They decide to return to Russia.

**Part Four** sees Anna and Vronsky in Petersburg. Vronsky's family and society reject Anna, making their position difficult. Anna, desperate to see Seryozha, attempts to visit him on his birthday. She manages to get into her former home and has a tearful reunion with her son, who still loves her despite being told she is "wicked." Alexey Alexandrovitch, influenced by Countess Lidia Ivanovna and a clairvoyant named Landau, refuses to grant Anna a divorce. Anna and Vronsky, frustrated by their unresolved status and the social isolation, decide to move to Moscow.

**Part Five** focuses on the Levins' married life in Moscow and the country. Kitty becomes pregnant. Levin struggles with the practicalities of married life and his ongoing philosophical doubts. He is still trying to implement his new farming system, but it proves difficult. He is also concerned about Dolly's financial difficulties and Stiva's continued irresponsibility. Vassenka Veslovsky, a charming but frivolous cousin, visits the Levins, causing Levin to become intensely jealous of his interactions with Kitty. Levin, in a fit of rage, expels Veslovsky from his house.

Levin's brother, Nikolay, becomes critically ill. Levin and Kitty travel to his deathbed. Kitty, with her practical and compassionate nature, takes charge of Nikolay's care, comforting him and ensuring he receives the last rites. Levin, witnessing his brother's suffering and death, is again confronted with the enigma of existence. He finds solace in Kitty's unwavering faith and love, and the news of her pregnancy fills him with a new sense of purpose and apprehension.

**Part Six** sees Dolly visiting Anna and Vronsky at their country estate, Vozdvizhenskoe. Dolly is initially impressed by their luxurious lifestyle and Anna's apparent happiness, but she also notices Anna's underlying sadness and the unnaturalness of her situation. Vronsky, seeking to legitimize his daughter and marry Anna, asks Dolly to persuade Anna to write to Alexey Alexandrovitch for a divorce. Anna, however, is conflicted. She fears losing Seryozha and is unwilling to humiliate herself further. She also reveals she has undergone a procedure to prevent further pregnancies, which shocks Dolly. Anna is increasingly irritable and jealous, convinced Vronsky's love is waning. She feels trapped and isolated.

**Part Seven** continues with Anna's growing despair. She and Vronsky move to Moscow, but their relationship is strained by her jealousy and his perceived coldness. Anna feels Vronsky is pulling away, seeking independence. She becomes convinced he no longer loves her and is ashamed of her. She considers suicide as a way to punish him and regain his love. After a final, bitter quarrel, Anna, in a state of extreme emotional distress, goes to the railway station. She recalls the man crushed by a train when she first met Vronsky. In a moment of terror and despair, she throws herself under an oncoming train, dying instantly.

**Part Eight** deals with the aftermath of Anna's death and Levin's spiritual journey. Sergey Ivanovitch's book has failed to make an impact, but he finds new purpose in the Slavonic question and the Servian War. He travels to the country with Katavasov, observing the volunteers. He meets Countess Vronskaya, who recounts Vronsky's despair and suicide attempt after Anna's death, and condemns Anna as a "bad woman." Vronsky, consumed by grief and guilt, decides to go to Servia with a squadron he funds himself, seeking a purpose in war.

Levin, meanwhile, is deeply affected by Anna's death and Vronsky's suffering. He continues his work on his estate, but his philosophical doubts about the meaning of life persist. He is tormented by the idea of death and the apparent meaninglessness of existence. He finds himself on the brink of suicide. However, through a conversation with a simple peasant, Fyodor, who says he lives "for his soul," Levin experiences a profound spiritual awakening. He realizes that the meaning of life is not found through reason or intellectual pursuits, but through faith in God and living for goodness. He understands that this knowledge is innate, "given" to all men, and that his previous intellectual struggles were a "deceitfulness of intellect." He embraces this new faith, finding peace and a positive meaning in his life, despite its ordinary struggles and imperfections. He feels a renewed sense of purpose in his family life and his work on the land, now guided by this inner conviction. He concludes that his life, with its goodness, is no longer meaningless.

The story begins on a hot July evening with a young man named Raskolnikov, who is deeply in debt to his landlady and avoids meeting her. He lives in a tiny garret in S. Place and is in an irritable, isolated state, crushed by poverty. He contemplates a "plan" he has been considering for a month, viewing it as an "exploit." He is poorly dressed, and an encounter with a drunken man who calls him "German hatter" makes him realize his noticeable hat could jeopardize his plan.

Raskolnikov proceeds to a large house, familiar with its back staircase, to the fourth floor where an old pawnbroker, Alyona Ivanovna, lives. He notes that a German clerk is moving out, leaving the old woman alone on that floor. He rings her bell, and she, a withered woman of sixty with suspicious eyes, lets him in. He presents an old silver watch to pawn. Alyona Ivanovna reminds him his previous pledge is due and offers him only 1.15 roubles for the watch. Raskolnikov, though angry, accepts, but lingers to ask if her sister, Lizaveta, is always with her. Alyona Ivanovna dismisses his question. Raskolnikov leaves, feeling intense repulsion for his plan, calling it "nonsense."

He enters a tavern for the first time, feeling dizzy and thirsty. After a beer, his thoughts clear, and he dismisses his fears. There, he meets a drunk, retired government clerk named Marmeladov. Marmeladov, in a long, rambling confession, describes his extreme poverty, his wife Katerina Ivanovna (an educated officer's daughter now consumptive and prone to rages), and his children. He admits to selling his wife's belongings for drink and that his daughter, Sonia (from his first marriage), has become a prostitute (indicated by a "yellow ticket") to support the family. He recounts how Sonia silently gave Katerina Ivanovna 30 roubles, leading to a tearful reconciliation between them. Marmeladov confesses that he stole his recent earnings from Katerina Ivanovna and has been drunk for five days, even begging 30 copecks from Sonia that morning for more drink. He asks Raskolnikov if he pities him.

Raskolnikov accompanies Marmeladov home. They find Katerina Ivanovna in their small, disordered room, coughing and berating her children. She screams at Marmeladov for his drinking and lost clothes, then turns on Raskolnikov, accusing him of drinking with her husband. Other lodgers and the landlady, Amalia Lippevechsel, are present. As Raskolnikov leaves, he places some coppers on the window for the family. He later questions his act of charity, then reflects on the nature of man, wondering if he is a "scoundrel" or if "all the rest is prejudice."

The next day, Raskolnikov wakes up ill and irritable. His landlady threatens to report him to the police for unpaid rent. Nastasya, the servant, brings him a letter from his mother. The letter reveals that his sister, Dounia, has been working as a governess for the Svidrigaïlovs, where Mr. Svidrigaïlov made inappropriate advances. His wife, Marfa Petrovna, discovered this, publicly shamed Dounia, but later, after Svidrigaïlov provided proof of Dounia's innocence, she publicly cleared Dounia's name. Dounia is now engaged to Pyotr Petrovitch Luzhin, a wealthy, forty-five-year-old counsellor. Luzhin desires a poor wife who will be indebted to him. His mother and Dounia hope this marriage will secure Raskolnikov's future, enabling him to finish university and work for Luzhin. His mother and Dounia are coming to Petersburg soon.

Raskolnikov is enraged by the letter, seeing Dounia's marriage as a sacrifice for his sake. He vows to prevent it, declaring, "It is me or Luzhin!" He feels his own helplessness and poverty. Marmeladov's words, "Do you understand... what it means when you have absolutely nowhere to turn?" echo in his mind. His "plan" from a month ago now feels menacing. He encounters a drunk, disheveled young girl being followed by a dandy. Raskolnikov intervenes, giving a policeman money to help her, but then, in a sudden revulsion, tells the policeman to let them be. He reflects on the girl's likely fate as a prostitute and wonders if Dounia could face a similar one.

He remembers he was going to visit his old university comrade, Razumihin, for work. He decides he will visit Razumihin "on the next day after It, when It will be over." Overwhelmed, he falls asleep in a park. He has a vivid nightmare of his childhood, witnessing a peasant, Mikolka, brutally beating an old mare to death. He wakes in terror, realizing the dream's connection to his plan to kill Alyona Ivanovna. He feels he cannot commit the act and experiences a sense of relief and freedom.

However, on his way home, he overhears Lizaveta Ivanovna, the pawnbroker's sister, discussing with a huckster that she will be away from home at seven o'clock the next day. This means Alyona Ivanovna will be alone. This "chance" encounter solidifies his resolve. He recalls a previous time he overheard a student in a tavern discussing killing Alyona Ivanovna for her money, arguing it would be justified for the good of humanity.

The next morning, Raskolnikov, still ill, finds some bloodstains on his trousers, which he cuts off. He realizes he still has the stolen items in his pockets and hides them in a hole in his wall. He is summoned to the police station for an unpaid IOU to his landlady. Relieved it's not about the murder, he argues with the assistant superintendent, Ilya Petrovitch. He faints during the conversation. While recovering, he overhears the police discussing the pawnbroker's murder, mentioning a painter, Nikolay, who confessed after being found with the old woman's ear-rings and trying to hang himself. They also discuss how the door was found locked, then unlocked, suggesting the murderer was inside and slipped away. Raskolnikov realizes they suspect him.

He rushes home, hides the stolen items under a stone in a deserted courtyard. He feels a momentary triumph. He then visits Razumihin, who is concerned about his illness and offers him translation work. Raskolnikov, in a fit of irritation, takes the money and leaves, then returns it. On a bridge, he throws 20 copecks (given to him by a woman who mistook him for a beggar) into the Neva, feeling cut off from everything. He is woken by screams, hearing his landlady being beaten by Ilya Petrovitch. Nastasya tells him it was his "blood crying in your ears," not a real beating.

Razumihin, Zossimov (the doctor), and the messenger from Vahrushin visit Raskolnikov, who is still ill. He receives 35 roubles from his mother. Razumihin buys him new clothes and pays off his IOU. Razumihin tells him he raved about "ear-rings and chains" during his delirium. Zossimov diagnoses him with a "fixed idea" related to the murder. Luzhin arrives, and Raskolnikov, in a furious outburst, tells Dounia he will not allow her marriage and insults Luzhin. Luzhin leaves, enraged.

Sonia Marmeladov visits, inviting them to her father's funeral. Raskolnikov, in a strange state, asks her about her life and her family's suffering. He presses her, asking how she can live in such "filth" and degradation. He then confesses to her that he killed Alyona Ivanovna and Lizaveta. Sonia is horrified but embraces him, promising to follow him to Siberia to share his suffering. He gives her Lizaveta's cypress wood cross. He leaves, resolving to confess.

On his way to the police station, he publicly bows down and kisses the earth in the Hay Market, as Sonia had urged. He sees Sonia following him. At the police station, he finds Ilya Petrovitch. He learns that Svidrigaïlov has shot himself. Raskolnikov, pale and reeling, confesses to Ilya Petrovitch that he killed Alyona Ivanovna and Lizaveta with an axe and robbed them.

**EPILOGUE:**
Raskolnikov is confined to a prison in Siberia. His trial is straightforward as he confesses clearly and precisely, detailing every aspect of the crime, including the hidden items under the stone. The court is puzzled by his failure to use the stolen money and his lack of memory regarding the trinkets, concluding he committed the crime due to "temporary mental derangement" or "homicidal mania." Raskolnikov, however, states his motive was poverty and his confession was due to "heartfelt repentance." Due to extenuating circumstances (his past good deeds, like helping a student and rescuing children from a fire), he is sentenced to eight years of penal servitude.

During the trial, his mother, Pulcheria Alexandrovna, falls ill with a nervous disorder and partial derangement. Dounia and Razumihin move her out of Petersburg and concoct a story about Raskolnikov being away on business. His mother, however, forms her own delusion that he is in hiding from powerful enemies and will become a great statesman. She dies of brain fever within a fortnight, having revealed in her delirium that she knew more about his terrible fate.

Two months after Raskolnikov's confession, Dounia marries Razumihin. They plan to move to Siberia in five years to be with Raskolnikov. Sonia, using the money Svidrigaïlov gave her, follows Raskolnikov to Siberia. She visits him regularly in prison, at work, and in the hospital when he falls ill. The other convicts, initially hostile, grow to respect and love Sonia, calling her "Little mother Sofya Semyonovna."

While ill in the hospital, Raskolnikov has a dream of a plague that makes everyone mad, killing each other, and destroying the world, with only a few chosen ones surviving. This dream troubles him. After recovering, he is discharged. Sonia, who has also been ill, visits him at his work on the river bank. He is suddenly overcome with emotion, falls to her feet, and weeps, embracing her knees. Sonia understands his love, and a light of infinite happiness comes into her eyes. They both realize a new life is dawning for them, filled with love and the promise of resurrection. He takes up Sonia's New Testament, the book from which she read him the story of Lazarus. The story ends with the beginning of their new journey, a "gradual renewal of a man."

Gustav Aschenbach, a renowned writer in his fifties, takes a walk in Munich one spring afternoon, feeling overwrought from his demanding work. He finds himself at the North Cemetery, where he observes an unusual-looking, red-haired man with a pug nose and exposed teeth. This encounter leaves Aschenbach feeling a sudden, intense longing for travel and far-off places, a feeling he had long suppressed due to his disciplined life and dedication to his work. He experiences a vivid hallucination of a tropical swampland. Despite his usual aversion to extensive travel and his current struggle with a piece of writing, he decides he needs a break and plans a three-to-four-week trip to a pleasant resort in the South.

The narrative then delves into Aschenbach's background, detailing his successful literary career, his disciplined and solitary life, and his physical frailty. He was ennobled on his fiftieth birthday and settled in Munich after his wife's death, living a respectable life with his married daughter. His art, though celebrated, was built on immense personal effort and a constant struggle against his own weakness. He believed great art came "in spite of something" and his later style became more formal and dignified, moving away from youthful cynicism.

Two weeks after his Munich walk, Aschenbach departs. He travels by night train to Trieste, then by ship to Pola, and finally to an island in the Adriatic. However, he is dissatisfied with the island's weather and atmosphere, realizing his true destination is Venice. He quickly arranges to leave, boarding an old, decrepit steamer. On board, he is disturbed by the sight of an elderly man disguised as a youth with makeup, a wig, and false teeth, behaving boisterously with younger companions. Aschenbach feels a sense of "dream-like estrangement."

Upon arrival in Venice, the weather is grey and dreary. Aschenbach is repulsed by the drunken, grotesque behavior of the disguised old man. He takes a gondola, intending to go to the public steamboat dock for the Lido, but the insolent, unlicensed gondolier insists on taking him directly to the Lido by sea. Aschenbach, feeling helpless and strangely complacent, allows himself to be taken. When they arrive, the gondolier vanishes before Aschenbach can pay, leaving him to learn from a hotel employee that the man was unlicensed and he "rode for nothing."

Aschenbach checks into a beach hotel on the Lido. In the lobby, he sees a Polish family, including three girls, a governess, and a boy of about fourteen. He is immediately struck by the boy's "absolutely beautiful," godlike appearance, comparing him to Greek sculpture. The boy's luxurious attire contrasts sharply with his sisters' severe clothing, suggesting he is a pampered favorite, though Aschenbach also notes his pale, ivory skin, hinting at frailty. The boy's eyes briefly meet Aschenbach's as he enters the dining hall.

The next day, the weather remains poor, and Aschenbach considers leaving, recalling a past illness in Venice. However, at breakfast, he sees the beautiful boy again, who enters with "extraordinary charm." Aschenbach, captivated, decides to stay. On the beach, he observes the boy, whom he deduces is named Tadzio, playing with other children. He notices Tadzio's disdain for a Russian family and is "cheered and unstrung" by the boy's "childish fanaticism." He watches Tadzio bathing, emerging from the sea like a "frail god," inspiring Aschenbach with a sense of myth. He feels a "paternal affection" for Tadzio.

Later, in the hotel lift, Aschenbach sees Tadzio up close and notices his teeth are "jagged and pale," suggesting he is "sickly" and "will not grow old." Aschenbach feels a strange "gratification" at this thought. That afternoon, Aschenbach visits Venice, but the city's oppressive sultriness and crowded streets make him feel ill, confirming his earlier decision to leave. He plans to go to another watering place. He returns to the hotel, announces his departure, and prepares his luggage.

The next morning, Aschenbach regrets his hasty decision, wishing for another day on the beach. He is irritated by the hotel staff rushing his departure. Just as he is about to leave, Tadzio passes him in the lobby, their eyes meeting. Aschenbach silently bids Tadzio farewell, even speaking the words to himself. On the steamboat trip across the lagoon, Aschenbach is overcome with intense regret and misery, realizing his deep attachment to Venice and the impossibility of returning due to his health. He feels his physical defeat is "dishonourable."

At the station, in a moment of intense conflict, Aschenbach learns his large trunk has been mistakenly sent to Como. He is seized by "adventurous delight" and "unbelievable hilarity." He declares he cannot travel without his trunk and decides to return to the Lido hotel to await its return. He quickly arranges for his ticket to be redeemed and boards the hotel's motorboat back to the Lido. He laughs at this "comically dreamlike" mishap, seeing it as fate bringing him back. Back in his new, almost identical room, he is content to be back, but also disapproves of his own irresolution. He sees Tadzio returning from the sea and feels "the exhilaration of his blood, a conflict of pain and pleasure," realizing Tadzio was the true reason for his reluctance to leave. He makes a "spontaneous act of welcome, of calm acceptance."

Days turn into weeks of sunny weather. Aschenbach remains at the Lido, his luggage returned, fully unpacked. He is bewitched by the easy rhythm of life and the proximity of Venice. He sees Tadzio constantly, on the beach, in the hotel, and in the city. He wakes early to watch Tadzio, admiring his beauty, which he equates with "the beautiful itself, form as the thought of God." He feels a "drunkenness" and begins to write again, his style inspired by Tadzio's "godlike" form. He attempts to approach Tadzio on the beach but is overcome by emotion and retreats. He sends for more money, no longer considering going home. He dreams of Dionysian revels and classical myths, seeing Tadzio as Hyacinth, loved by two gods.

A tense, unspoken familiarity develops between Aschenbach and Tadzio, with the boy often walking unnecessarily close to Aschenbach's spot on the beach, and their glances meeting. One evening, after Tadzio's family dines in the city, Aschenbach sees Tadzio in a dark sailor suit. Their eyes meet, and Tadzio smiles at Aschenbach, a "deep, fascinated, magnetic smile" like Narcissus. Aschenbach is overwhelmed, flees to the dark park, and whispers, "I love you!"

In his fourth week, Aschenbach notices fewer guests and overhears the barber mention "the plague." He goes to Venice and detects a "peculiar odour" of sickness and disinfectant. He sees municipal warnings about gastric diseases, but the euphemistic language suggests a cover-up. He questions a shop proprietor, who dismisses it as a precaution. Back at the hotel, he reads newspapers, finding official denials amidst rumors, confirming his suspicion that cholera is rampant and being concealed to protect tourism. He feels a "dark contentment" with this "wicked secret," which aligns with his own hidden passion, terrified of Tadzio leaving.

He begins to stalk Tadzio, following him through Venice's labyrinthine streets, enduring "deadly agony" when he loses sight of him. He feels "drunk" and driven by a "demon." He even hires a gondola to secretly follow Tadzio's gondola. He stops outside Tadzio's hotel room, leaning his head against the door in "utter drunkenness." He has moments of lucidity, questioning his path and recalling his ancestors' strict principles, but ultimately embraces his "illicit experience" and the "advantages of chaos." He questions the hotel manager about disinfectants, receiving an evasive answer.

That evening, a band of street singers performs at the hotel. Aschenbach observes Tadzio nearby. The lead singer, a "buffo baritone" with a "vulgar" and "repulsive" performance, reminds Aschenbach of the man at the cemetery. A strong carbolic smell emanates from the singer. Aschenbach, his "passion lam[ing] the sense of discrimination," asks the singer about the disinfection, who denies any plague. Hotel employees question the singer for speaking out. Aschenbach notices Tadzio's "portentous childish obedience" in mirroring his seriousness, and also Tadzio's quick breathing, suggesting lung congestion. He thinks, "He is sickly, he will probably not grow old," with "rakish gratification."

The next day, Aschenbach goes to an English travel bureau and, after pressing the clerk, learns the full truth: Indian cholera has spread to Venice, with high fatalities, and the authorities are covering it up to protect trade. A quarantine is imminent. Aschenbach feels "feverishly excited, triumphant in his possession of the truth," but also "weird horror." He considers warning Tadzio's mother but realizes he doesn't truly want to, choosing instead to keep silent, intoxicated by his complicity in the city's secret.

That night, Aschenbach has a vivid, terrifying dream of a Dionysian orgy, a "raging mob" of people and beasts, with "wickedly persistent flutes" and the smell of "wounds and prevalent disease." He is drawn into the "blinding deafening lewdness," his soul tasting "unchastity and fury of decay." He awakens "unnerved, shattered, and hopelessly under the power of the demon." He no longer cares about being noticed. Guests are fleeing, but Tadzio's family remains. Aschenbach feels that flight and death might leave him alone with the boy, and "laws of morality had dropped away."

He tries to rejuvenate his appearance, visiting the barber to have his grey hair dyed black, curled, and his skin touched up with cosmetics. The barber declares, "Now the gentleman can fall in love unhesitatingly." Aschenbach leaves, feeling "happy as in a dream." A storm wind rises, and the air is filled with the smell of "things rotting." He pursues Tadzio through the diseased city, using "disgraceful subterfuges," and Tadzio occasionally looks back, acknowledging his admirer without betraying him. Aschenbach eventually loses Tadzio, exhausted and unnerved. He buys and eats overly ripe strawberries.

Sitting on the steps of a cistern, Aschenbach reflects on his past dignity as an artist and his current state of moral dissolution, concluding that the path of beauty for poets is a "perilous road" leading to "intoxication and to desire," to the "precipice." He declares that poets "cannot force ourselves, since we can merely let ourselves out."

A few days later, Aschenbach feels unwell, experiencing vertigo and hopelessness. He learns the Polish family is leaving after lunch. He goes to the beach, which now looks autumnal and abandoned. Tadzio and his few remaining companions are playing unsupervised. Tadzio is forced into a wrestling match by another boy, Jaschu, who then kneels on Tadzio's back, pressing his face into the sand, nearly strangling him. Aschenbach is about to intervene when Jaschu releases Tadzio.

Tadzio, pale and rumpled, sits up, then slowly walks to the water's edge, drawing figures in the sand. He wades into the shallow sea and walks along a sand-bank, isolated. He stops, turns, and looks over his shoulder towards the shore, towards Aschenbach. Aschenbach, watching, feels as though Tadzio's "pale and lovely lure" is smiling and nodding to him, guiding him "towards egregious promises." As often before, Aschenbach stands up to follow him.

Minutes later, Aschenbach collapses in his chair. On the same day, the world receives news of his death.

The story begins in a village in La Mancha, introducing a gentleman of nearly fifty who lives with a housekeeper, a niece, and a lad. He spends most of his income on food and clothing, and his leisure time is consumed by reading books of chivalry. His obsession with these tales leads him to neglect his property, selling land to acquire more books. Eventually, from lack of sleep and excessive reading, he loses his wits and comes to believe that all the events described in these books are true.

Driven by this delusion, he decides to become a knight-errant himself, intending to roam the world in full armor, seeking adventures, righting wrongs, and achieving eternal renown. He imagines himself becoming an emperor. His first step is to clean his great-grandfather's rusty armor. Finding it lacks a closed helmet, he improvises a half-helmet from pasteboard. After a test slash with his sword destroys it, he reinforces it with iron bars and deems it perfect. He then spends four days naming his lean hack, settling on "Rocinante." Next, he names himself "Don Quixote," and adds "of La Mancha" to his name, following the tradition of famous knights. Finally, he realizes he needs a lady to be in love with. He chooses Aldonza Lorenzo, a farm-girl from a nearby village whom he once admired, and renames her "Dulcinea del Toboso."

One hot July morning, Don Quixote, fully armored, sallies forth on Rocinante. He is immediately struck by the realization that he has not been dubbed a knight, a crucial requirement of chivalry. He resolves to be knighted by the first person he encounters. He rides along, imagining a chronicler recording his deeds and addressing his lady. Towards nightfall, tired and hungry, he arrives at an inn, which he perceives as a magnificent castle. He sees two young women, whom he mistakes for fair maidens or ladies, and a swineherd's horn blast sounds to him like a dwarf announcing his arrival. He courteously addresses the frightened women, assuring them he is a knight. The innkeeper, a fat man, emerges, amused by Don Quixote's appearance but also somewhat intimidated. Don Quixote, mistaking the innkeeper for the "Alcaide of the fortress," requests lodging. He is given ill-cooked stockfish and black bread, which he struggles to eat due to his helmet, requiring one of the women to feed him. He drinks wine through a reed. The sowgelder's pipe further confirms his delusion that he is being regaled with music in a famous castle. Despite this, he remains distressed about not being formally knighted.

To remedy this, Don Quixote kneels before the innkeeper in the stable, demanding to be dubbed a knight. The innkeeper, recognizing his guest's madness, decides to humor him. He claims there is no chapel but suggests Don Quixote watch his arms in the courtyard. He also advises Don Quixote to carry money and clean shirts, as true knights-errant do. Don Quixote agrees and places his armor on a trough by a well, beginning his vigil. A carrier attempts to water his mules, needing to move the armor. Don Quixote warns him, but the carrier flings the armor away. Don Quixote invokes Dulcinea and strikes the carrier with his lance, knocking him senseless. He replaces his armor. Another carrier attempts the same, and Don Quixote strikes him, splitting his head. A brawl ensues, with the carriers stoning Don Quixote. The innkeeper intervenes, explaining Don Quixote is mad. The stoning stops. The innkeeper, eager to end the trouble, performs a mock knighting ceremony, using his account-book as a prayer book and striking Don Quixote with his sword. The two damsels gird his sword and buckle his spur. Don Quixote, now "knighted," thanks the host and rides off on Rocinante, leaving without paying.

Don Quixote, elated, decides to return home to gather money, shirts, and a squire. He plans to recruit a farm-laborer named Sancho Panza. On his way, he hears cries and finds a youth, Andres, being flogged by a farmer. Don Quixote intervenes, ordering the farmer to pay Andres his wages. The farmer, terrified, agrees. Don Quixote, satisfied, rides off. However, as soon Quixote is out of sight, the farmer flogs Andres again, mocking Don Quixote. Andres vows to find Don Quixote. Unaware of this, Don Quixote congratulates himself. He then encounters a party of Toledo traders, whom he mistakes for knights. He demands they confess Dulcinea's unparalleled beauty. One trader mockingly asks for a portrait. Enraged, Don Quixote charges, but Rocinante stumbles, throwing him. A muleteer beats Don Quixote with a piece of his broken lance. Don Quixote, though battered, believes this is a typical knightly mishap. A peasant from his village finds him, recognizes him, and helps him onto his ass. Don Quixote, still deluded, recounts chivalric tales, mistaking the peasant for a marquis. They arrive at Don Quixote's house, where his housekeeper, niece, the curate, and the barber are discussing his madness. The curate resolves to burn his books. Don Quixote is put to bed, claiming his bruises are from fighting giants.

The next day, while Don Quixote is asleep, the curate, barber, and housekeeper enter his library. They burn most of his books of chivalry, sparing only a few they deem less harmful or well-written. They then wall up the library, planning to tell Don Quixote a magician carried the books away. Don Quixote, upon waking, discovers his library gone and is told by his niece and housekeeper that the sage Friston, his enemy, enchanted and carried away his books. Don Quixote accepts this, believing Friston is trying to thwart his glorious destiny. He then persuades Sancho Panza to become his squire, promising him the governorship of an island. Sancho, leaving his family, agrees. Don Quixote procures money and a buckler. Sancho brings his ass, Dapple, which Don Quixote reluctantly allows. They set out at night.

As they travel, Sancho eagerly anticipates his island. They soon encounter thirty or forty windmills, which Don Quixote declares are monstrous giants. Sancho tries to convince him they are windmills, but Don Quixote, convinced by his delusion, charges. His lance breaks, and he and Rocinante are thrown to the ground. Sancho helps him, scolding him. Don Quixote attributes the transformation to Friston. He laments his broken lance and resolves to make a new one from an oak branch. He, though injured, refuses to complain, citing knightly custom, but allows Sancho to complain. Sancho eats and drinks from his provisions. They spend the night in the woods.

The next day, they head towards Puerto Lapice. Don Quixote warns Sancho not to intervene if he fights knights. They encounter two Benedictine friars and a coach with a lady. Don Quixote believes the friars are magicians abducting a princess. He charges the first friar, who falls from his mule. Sancho attempts to strip the friar, claiming spoils, but the muleteers beat Sancho senseless. Don Quixote then addresses the lady, claiming to have rescued her and demanding she go to El Toboso to present herself to Dulcinea. A Biscayan squire from the coach, angered, challenges Don Quixote. They fight, and the Biscayan wounds Don Quixote, damaging his helmet and ear. Don Quixote strikes back, knocking the Biscayan from his mule. The ladies intervene, and Don Quixote agrees to spare the Biscayan on condition he present himself to Dulcinea.

Sancho, recovered, asks for his promised island. Don Quixote explains this was not an island adventure. Don Quixote, seeing his shattered helmet, vows an oath of vengeance to not eat from a tablecloth or embrace his wife until he takes another helmet. Sancho objects to the oath and the lack of practical rewards. Don Quixote dismisses his concerns. They spend the night with goatherds. Don Quixote delivers a long discourse on the Golden Age. A goatherd, Antonio, sings a ballad of unrequited love. Another goatherd tells them of Chrysostom, a student-shepherd who died of love for the beautiful but scornful Marcela. They decide to attend Chrysostom's burial.

At the burial, Marcela appears and eloquently defends her right to remain chaste and free, stating she is not to blame for Chrysostom's death. Don Quixote, moved, defends her and warns anyone against following her. Chrysostom's writings are burned, and his body is buried. Don Quixote resolves to seek Marcela.

Don Quixote and Sancho search for Marcela without success. They rest, and Rocinante attempts to mate with some ponies, leading to him being beaten by Yanguesan carriers. Don Quixote and Sancho intervene but are severely beaten themselves. Sancho asks for the balsam of Fierabras. Don Quixote blames himself for fighting non-knights and promises to make the balsam. Sancho, in pain, suggests returning home. Don Quixote, now missing several teeth, insists on continuing. They find a valise containing money and letters, which Don Quixote believes belong to a desperate lover. Sancho takes the money. They see a ragged man (Cardenio) and suspect he is the owner.

That night, they encounter a funeral procession of encamisados (men in white) and mourners. Don Quixote, mistaking it for an abduction, attacks them, wounding a licentiate. Sancho loots a sumpter mule. Don Quixote, now calling himself "Knight of the Rueful Countenance," learns the procession is carrying a dead body. The licentiate warns him of excommunication. Sancho, fearing the Holy Brotherhood, urges retreat. They find a secluded valley and eat the stolen provisions.

They hear a mysterious noise of water and chains. Don Quixote believes it's a perilous adventure and declares his intention to go alone, telling Sancho to wait three days and then inform Dulcinea of his death. Sancho, terrified, ties Rocinante's legs to prevent his master from leaving. Don Quixote, believing it's enchantment, agrees to wait for dawn. Sancho tells a long, rambling story about goats. At daybreak, they discover the noise comes from fulling hammers. Don Quixote is mortified, and Sancho laughs, earning him a beating from his master. Don Quixote then explains enchanters make things appear different.

They encounter a barber wearing a brass basin on his head. Don Quixote, mistaking it for Mambrino's helmet, charges and unhorses him, claiming the basin. Sancho laughs, but Don Quixote insists it's the enchanted helmet. Sancho swaps Dapple's trappings for the barber's. Sancho suggests they serve an emperor to gain fame and rewards. Don Quixote agrees, envisioning a grand career culminating in kingship and rewarding Sancho. He describes Dulcinea's beauty and noble lineage, though Sancho knows her as a farm-girl. Don Quixote, angered by Sancho's blasphemy against Dulcinea, beats him. Sancho, still pragmatic, suggests marrying the princess first. They then encounter Gines de Pasamonte, who stole Dapple, and Sancho reclaims his ass.

They return to the inn. The curate and barber, having heard of Don Quixote's madness, disguise themselves as a distressed damsel and squire to lure him home. Sancho is instructed to tell Don Quixote that Dulcinea, being illiterate, sent a verbal command for him to return. Don Quixote, still believing the inn is a castle, is greeted by Dorothea (the disguised barber), who kneels and begs him to avenge a giant who usurped her kingdom (Micomicon). Don Quixote agrees. Sancho is thrilled, imagining himself as king of Micomicon. Don Quixote, however, declares his unwavering devotion to Dulcinea, leading to another beating for Sancho. The curate and Cardenio, also disguised, join them. The barber's false beard falls off, but the curate quickly reattaches it with a "charm."

Dorothea, continuing her feigned story, explains her father, King Tinacrio, foretold Don Quixote would defeat the giant Pandafilando and marry her. Sancho is overjoyed, but Don Quixote again refuses marriage due to Dulcinea. Sancho, angered, is beaten again. Sancho then recounts his "visit" to Dulcinea, claiming she was sifting wheat and smelled "goaty," but Don Quixote insists it was enchantment. Andres, the flogged boy, reappears, blaming Don Quixote for his worse beating. Don Quixote vows to avenge him later.

The duke and duchess, having read the first part of Don Quixote's history, decide to play along. They arrange a hunting party. During a boar hunt, Sancho, terrified, falls from a tree and hangs upside down. He is rescued. That night, a series of "enchantments" are staged: lights, military sounds, and a demon courier announcing that the sage Montesinos is bringing Dulcinea, enchanted, to give instructions for her disenchantment. Three carts appear with "sages" (Lirgandeo, Alquife, Archelaus). Finally, a triumphal car with a nymph (Altisidora, disguised as Dulcinea) and Merlin appears. Merlin declares Dulcinea's disenchantment requires Sancho to receive 3,300 lashes on his bare buttocks. Sancho vehemently refuses. Altisidora, unveiling her beautiful face, tearfully pleads with Sancho. Sancho, after much protest and the duke's pressure, agrees to the lashes, on his own terms.

The duke and duchess, delighted, continue their jokes. Sancho tells the duchess he gave himself five lashes with his hand. He gives her a letter for his wife, Teresa Panza, informing her of his governorship and the whipping. Trifaldin of the White Beard (the majordomo in disguise) arrives with twelve bearded duennas, recounting their tale of being cursed with beards by the giant Malambruno. Don Quixote vows to help. Clavileño the Swift, a wooden flying horse, arrives. Sancho, after much reluctance, agrees to mount it with Don Quixote. They are blindfolded. The duke and duchess's servants use bellows, tow, and squibs to simulate a fiery, high-speed flight. Sancho peeks and claims to see the earth as a mustard seed and men as hazelnuts, and to have played with goats in heaven. Clavileño explodes, throwing them to the ground. A placard announces the duennas are shaved and Clavijo and Antonomasia are restored, and Dulcinea's disenchantment awaits Sancho's whipping.

Sancho is appointed governor of the "island" of Barataria. He presides over several cases, displaying surprising wisdom. In one, he discovers money hidden in a cane. In another, he resolves a dispute between a woman and a pig dealer, and a tailor and a laborer. Don Quixote, meanwhile, is recovering from cat scratches. Altisidora, feigning love, serenades him. A staged "bell and cat fright" occurs, with cats attacking Don Quixote, leaving him with a scratched face and nose. Altisidora bandages him, blaming his insensibility.

Sancho, still governor, receives a letter from Don Quixote with advice on governing. Sancho dictates a reply, complaining about the doctor who starves him and the constant threats. That night, a staged attack on the island occurs. Sancho is "armed" with two shields, front and back, and bound, then trampled by the "enemy." He prays for the island to be lost. The "attackers" declare victory. Sancho, bruised and disillusioned, resigns his governorship, embracing Dapple and declaring he was not born to govern. He returns to Don Quixote.

The duke and duchess arrange a combat between Don Quixote and Tosilos (the lacquey disguised as a knight) for Doña Rodriguez's daughter. Tosilos, however, falls in love with the daughter and yields, offering to marry her. Don Quixote accepts his victory. The lacquey's identity is revealed, causing an uproar. Don Quixote attributes it to enchanters. The marriage is postponed.

Don Quixote decides to leave the castle. Altisidora sings a farewell lament, accusing him of theft and cursing him. Don Quixote denies the theft. He and Sancho depart for Barcelona. On the way, they encounter Roque Guinart, a famous highwayman. Roque and his men rob Sancho, but Roque later returns the items and distributes loot fairly. A young woman, Claudia Jeronima, tells Roque she shot her fiancé, Don Vicente, for betraying her. Roque and Claudia find Don Vicente dying. Claudia, distraught, faints, and Don Vicente dies. Claudia resolves to become a nun.

In Barcelona, Don Quixote is welcomed by Don Antonio Moreno. A placard is secretly placed on Don Quixote's back, identifying him. A Castilian insults him. Don Antonio shows Don Quixote an "enchanted head" that answers questions (a trick). Don Quixote asks about Montesinos's cave and Dulcinea's disenchantment; the head gives vague answers. Sancho asks about future governments and his family; the head gives equally vague answers. Don Quixote visits a printing office and discovers a false "Second Part of Don Quixote." He is indignant about the errors.

Don Quixote and Sancho visit the galleys. Sancho is subjected to a "flight" ceremony, being passed along the rowers. A corsair brigantine is captured. A young woman, Ana Felix, reveals she is a Christian Morisco, returning from Algiers with Don Gaspar Gregorio (her lover, disguised as a woman) and buried treasure. Her father, Ricote, a pilgrim, is also present. They are reunited. A plan is made to rescue Don Gaspar.

Don Quixote, still on the beach, is challenged by the Knight of the White Moon. The knight demands Don Quixote confess his lady is fairer than Dulcinea or fight. If Don Quixote loses, he must return home for a year. Don Quixote accepts. In the combat, Don Quixote is unhorsed. He confesses Dulcinea is the fairest and he the most unfortunate, and agrees to return home for a year. The Knight of the White Moon reveals himself to be the bachelor Samson Carrasco, who devised this plan to cure Don Quixote's madness. Don Gregorio is rescued.

Don Quixote and Sancho begin their journey home. Sancho complains about not being paid for his lashes. Don Quixote offers to pay him. Sancho calculates the amount and agrees to finish the whipping that night. He whips trees, groaning, until Don Quixote stops him, believing he has given over a thousand lashes. Don Quixote proposes they become shepherds for the year, he as Quixotize, Sancho as Panzino. Sancho is enthusiastic. They are trampled by a drove of pigs. Don Quixote attributes it to enchantment. They are then captured by armed men and taken back to the duke's castle.

Another "enchantment" is staged. Altisidora is placed on a catafalque, seemingly dead. Merlin appears and declares Altisidora will be revived if Sancho receives smacks, pinches, and pin thrusts. Sancho, after much protest, submits. Altisidora revives. Don Quixote again urges Sancho to complete his lashes for Dulcinea. Altisidora, feigning anger, dismisses Don Quixote.

Don Quixote and Sancho finally reach their village. Don Quixote interprets some boys' words and a hare chase as bad omens. Sancho, however, dismisses them. They meet the curate and bachelor. Don Quixote tells them of his defeat and his plan to become a shepherd for a year. His friends, hoping to cure him, agree to join him.

Don Quixote falls ill with a fever. After six days, he wakes up, his reason restored. He denounces books of chivalry as absurdities and deceptions, regretting his madness. He declares himself Alonso Quixano the Good and wishes to die in his right mind. His friends are astonished. Sancho weeps, begging him not to die and to continue their pastoral life. Don Quixote makes his will, forgiving Sancho, leaving his property to his niece (with a condition that she not marry anyone who knows about chivalry books), and asking forgiveness from the author of the false "Second Part." Don Quixote dies peacefully in his bed, like a Christian. The notary records his natural death to prevent further false histories. Cide Hamete concludes the story, stating Don Quixote was born for him, and he for Don Quixote, and that his purpose was to expose the folly of chivalry books.

Jonathan Harker, a young English solicitor, travels to Bistritz, Transylvania, in May to finalize a London property purchase for a nobleman named Count Dracula. Along his journey, he observes the local customs and superstitions, noting the fear of "evil eye" and "were-wolves or vampires" among the peasants.
