She married them in her castle and promised to reconcile them with their families. After enjoying their love, they returned to Rome, where the lady helped them make peace with Pietro's family. They lived happily to old age.

**Story 4: Ricciardo Manardi (Filostrato)**
Filostrato tells of Messer Lizio da Valbona, a worthy gentleman in Romagna, who had a beautiful and agreeable daughter, Caterina, late in his old age. He and his wife, Madam Giacomina, guarded her diligently. Ricciardo Manardi, a handsome young man, often visited Messer Lizio's house and fell in love with Caterina, who returned his affection. They secretly confessed their love. Ricciardo proposed they meet in the gallery adjoining Caterina's father's garden. Caterina agreed.

To achieve this, Caterina complained to her mother about the heat, suggesting she sleep in the gallery to hear the nightingale. Her father initially scoffed, saying she'd sleep to the "chirp of the crickets." But after another sleepless night for Caterina, her mother persuaded him. A bed was made in the gallery. That night, Messer Lizio locked the door to the gallery from his chamber. Ricciardo, using a ladder and handholds, climbed to the gallery, where Caterina joyfully received him. They made love throughout the night, making the "nightingale sing many a time."

As dawn approached, they fell asleep, naked and embraced, Caterina holding Ricciardo by his genitals. Messer Lizio awoke, curious to see how the nightingale had made Caterina sleep. He quietly opened the door to the gallery, drew back the curtain, and saw them. Recognizing Ricciardo, he went to his wife, telling her to come see how their daughter had caught the nightingale. Madam Giacomina, initially shocked, wanted to scold them, but Messer Lizio, calm, decided to turn the scandal into an honorable marriage. Ricciardo was young, rich, and well-born, and would make a good son-in-law.

Ricciardo awoke, terrified to be discovered. Messer Lizio, lifting the curtain, said, "We shall do well." Ricciardo begged for mercy. Messer Lizio offered him a choice: marry Caterina or die. Caterina, weeping, also urged him to marry her. Ricciardo, eager to escape death and possess his beloved, readily agreed. Messer Lizio, using his wife's ring, married them on the spot. The parents left them to rest. They continued their lovemaking. A few days later, they were formally married, and Ricciardo took Caterina home, where they lived happily, "nightingale-fowling" to their hearts' content.

**Story 5: Giannole di Severino and Minghino di Mingole (Neifile)**
Neifile tells of Guidotto da Cremona, an old Lombard soldier in Fano, who on his deathbed entrusted his ten-year-old daughter to his friend Giacomino da Pavia, along with all his wealth. Giacomino moved to Faenza with the girl, whom he loved as his own. She grew into a beautiful and virtuous fifteen-year-old. Two agreeable young men, Giannole di Severino and Minghino di Mingole, fell in love with her, becoming rivals. Their families would not permit marriage due to her unknown origins.

Giannole bribed Crivello, Giacomino's servant, to let him into the house when Giacomino was out. Minghino bribed the maidservant with a similar promise. One evening, Giacomino went to supper. Crivello signaled Giannole, and the maid signaled Minghino. Both lovers arrived with armed companions, unaware of each other. Giannole entered first and tried to abduct the girl. She and the maid screamed. Minghino, hearing the commotion, rushed in with his men. A fight ensued. Neighbors intervened, and Minghino rescued the girl, returning her to Giacomino's house. Many were arrested, including Giannole, Minghino, and Crivello.

Giacomino, returning home, was upset but, finding the girl blameless, decided to marry her quickly. The kinsmen of the imprisoned youths pleaded with Giacomino. He revealed that the girl was not from Cremona or Pavia, but a Faentine, though her parentage was unknown. He recounted Guidotto's deathbed confession: he had found the two-year-old girl in a plundered house in Faenza during Emperor Frederick's capture of the city.

Guiglielmino da Medicina, present, recognized the story and identified the plundered house as Bernabuccio's. Bernabuccio, also present, remembered losing a young daughter during the sack of Faenza and a cross-shaped scar over her left ear. He asked to see the girl. Giacomino agreed. Bernabuccio saw her resemblance to her mother and found the scar, confirming she was his daughter. He embraced her, and she, sensing a connection, wept with him. Bernabuccio sent for his wife and family, and the reunion was joyous. The town-captain, learning Giannole was Bernabuccio's son and thus the girl's brother, released him, Minghino, and Crivello. He then arranged the marriage of Agnesa (the girl's true name) to Minghino. Minghino and Agnesa lived happily.

**Story 6: Gianni di Procida (Pampinea)**
Pampinea tells of Gianni di Procida, a youth from the island of Procida, who loved Restituta, daughter of Marino Bolgaro of Ischia. She loved him equally. Gianni often swam from Procida to Ischia to see her. One summer day, Restituta, alone on the seashore, was abducted by Sicilian corsairs and taken to Calabria. Unable to agree on who should have her, they presented her to King Frederick of Sicily, who was young and enjoyed such gifts. He ordered her lodged in a beautiful pavilion in his garden, La Cuba, until he recovered from an illness.

Gianni, hearing of her abduction and the direction the corsairs took, sailed to Palermo. He discovered she was with the King at La Cuba. Despairing, he sent his pinnace away and stayed in Palermo. He saw Restituta at a window, and she saw him. She instructed him on how to enter the garden. That night, Gianni climbed into the garden and then into her chamber through an open window. Restituta, believing her honor already compromised and seeing Gianni as her only hope, decided to yield to him and asked him to take her away. Gianni agreed, promising to arrange their escape. They made love and fell asleep in each other's arms.

The King, recovered and desiring Restituta, went to La Cuba with servants. He entered her chamber and found them naked and asleep together. Enraged, he almost killed them but decided on a public execution by fire. He ordered them bound and taken to Palermo's public square to be burned at tierce (9 a.m.). The townspeople flocked to see them. The wretched lovers, ashamed and fearing death, awaited their fate.

Ruggieri dell' Oria, the King's admiral, heard the news. He recognized Gianni di Procida and asked him what had happened. Gianni confessed his love and the King's anger. Gianni then begged Ruggieri to turn them face-to-face so he could die looking at his beloved. Ruggieri, laughing, promised he would see her until he grew weary. Ruggieri then went to the King, arguing that the lovers' offense, born of love, did not deserve death, especially since Gianni's uncle, Messer Gian di Procida, was instrumental in making Frederick King of Sicily, and Restituta's father was also influential. He reminded the King of the good deeds of their families.

The King, realizing the truth and regretting his rashness, ordered their release. He clothed them sumptuously, married them, and gave them magnificent presents. They returned to Ischia, where they were received with great joy.

**Story 7: Teodoro (Lauretta)**
Lauretta tells of Messer Amerigo Abate of Trapani, who bought several boys, believing them Turks, from Genoese corsairs. Among them was Teodoro, a noble-looking boy. Amerigo freed him, baptized him Pietro, and made him chief of his affairs. Pietro fell in love with Amerigo's daughter, Violante, who returned his love. They secretly met in a ruined hut at Amerigo's country estate. Violante became pregnant. Pietro, fearing for his life, wanted to flee, but Violante convinced him to stay, promising to protect him.

Violante, unable to hide her pregnancy, confessed to her mother, fabricating a story to protect Pietro. Her mother sent her to the country house. One day, Amerigo, returning from hawking, unexpectedly found Violante giving birth. Enraged, he demanded to know the father. Violante, fearing death, revealed Pietro. Amerigo, furious, reported Pietro to Messer Currado, the King's captain. Pietro was tortured and confessed. He was condemned to be flogged through the city and then hanged. Amerigo, still enraged, sent a servant to Violante with a poisoned cup and a dagger, ordering her to choose her death, or be burned alive. He also ordered the servant to kill the newborn child.

As Pietro was being scourged through the city, three Armenian noblemen, ambassadors to Rome, saw him. One, Fineo, recognized a birthmark on Pietro's chest, a "vermeil spot... after the fashion of what women here call roses." He realized Pietro was his son Teodoro, abducted fifteen years prior. Fineo called out, and Pietro, hearing his true name, confirmed his identity and parentage. Fineo, weeping, embraced him, clothed him in his own rich mantle, and asked the officer to delay the execution.

Fineo then went to Messer Currado, revealing Pietro's true identity and noble birth, and stating that Pietro was willing to marry Violante. Currado, ashamed of the injustice, released Pietro. He then informed Amerigo, who, believing his daughter and grandson dead, was distraught. He sent a messenger to stop his orders. The messenger arrived just as Violante was about to choose between poison and dagger. He stopped the servant. Amerigo, relieved, agreed to the marriage. Teodoro and Violante were married with great magnificence. Violante recovered and became more beautiful. Fineo, taking his son, daughter-in-law, and grandson, returned to Lazistan, where they lived happily.

**Story 8: Nastagio degli Onesti (Filomena)**
Filomena tells of Nastagio degli Onesti, a wealthy young man in Ravenna, who loved a proud and cruel lady of the Traversari family. His lavish efforts to win her love were in vain. His friends advised him to leave Ravenna to forget her and curb his spending. He reluctantly agreed, moving to Chiassi, three miles away, where he continued to live magnificently.

One day in May, lost in thought about his cruel mistress, he wandered into a pine wood. He heard terrible w wailing and saw a beautiful naked damsel running through thorns, pursued by two fierce mastiffs and a knight in black armor, who threatened her with death. Nastagio, terrified but moved by compassion, tried to intervene. The knight revealed himself as Messer Guido degli Anastagi, a fellow Ravennese, who had loved the damsel (who was the lady Nastagio loved) in his lifetime. She had been cruel to him, and he had killed himself in despair. She, rejoicing in his death, also died. For her cruelty and his suicide, they were both condemned to a hellish penance: he must eternally pursue and kill her every Friday in that wood, tear out her heart and entrails, and feed them to the dogs, after which she would rise again to flee. This punishment would continue for as many years as she had been cruel to him months.

Nastagio, horrified, retreated. He realized this vision could serve his purpose. He marked the spot and invited his kinsmen, Messer Paolo Traversari, his wife, and his daughter (Nastagio's beloved) to a magnificent dinner in that very pine wood the following Friday. As the last dish was served, the ghostly chase began. The lady, the knight, and the dogs appeared, reenacting the gruesome scene. The ladies present, many of whom were kinswomen of the ghostly damsel, wept.

Nastagio's cruel mistress, witnessing this, was terrified. She realized the vision was a warning for her own cruelty towards Nastagio. Fearing a similar fate, she immediately sent her chamberwoman to Nastagio, offering her love. Nastagio replied he would only accept her as his wife. She agreed, and her parents, overjoyed, arranged the marriage. Nastagio and his lady married the next Sunday and lived long and happily. This terrifying event also made all the ladies of Ravenna more amenable to their lovers' desires.

**Story 9: Federigo degli Alberighi (Fiammetta)**
Fiammetta tells of Federigo degli Alberighi, a noble Florentine renowned for arms and courtesy, who fell in love with Madam Giovanna, a virtuous and beautiful lady. To win her love, he squandered all his wealth on jousts, entertainments, and gifts. She, however, remained indifferent. Federigo became poor, with only a small farm and his prized falcon, one of the best in the world. He moved to his farm, living meagerly, hunting with his falcon.

Madam Giovanna's husband fell ill and died, leaving his son as heir, with Giovanna as his substitute if the son died without issue. Giovanna moved to a country estate near Federigo's. Her son befriended Federigo and became fascinated by his falcon, longing to own it. The boy fell ill, and his mother, desperate, promised him anything to make him well. He asked for Federigo's falcon.

Giovanna was conflicted. She knew Federigo's love for her and that the falcon was his last possession. She felt it ungracious to ask for it. But her son's love compelled her. She promised to get the falcon. The next morning, she visited Federigo with another lady, ostensibly for a friendly dinner. Federigo, overjoyed but ashamed of his poverty, welcomed her. He realized he had nothing worthy to serve such a noble guest. His eyes fell on his falcon. Having no other resource, he wrung its neck and had his maid roast it diligently.

At dinner, Federigo served the falcon, and the ladies ate it, unaware. After dinner, Giovanna revealed her purpose, explaining her son's illness and his desire for the falcon. She begged Federigo to give it to her, appealing to his nobility. Federigo, weeping, confessed he could not grant her request because he had just served her the falcon for dinner. He showed her the feathers, feet, and beak as proof.

Giovanna first blamed him for killing such a falcon for a meal but then greatly admired his magnanimity, which poverty could not diminish. She returned to her son, distraught. Soon after, her son died. After a period of mourning, her brothers urged her to remarry. She, recalling Federigo's worth and his ultimate sacrifice, declared she would marry no one but him, saying, "I would liefer have a man that lacketh of riches than riches that lack of a man." Her brothers, though initially mocking, agreed. Federigo married Giovanna, becoming rich again, and lived happily, managing his wealth more wisely.

**Story 10: Pietro di Vinciolo (Dioneo)**
Dioneo tells of Pietro di Vinciolo, a rich man in Perugia, who married the beautiful and lusty Peronella, more to conceal his own homosexual inclinations than from desire for her. Peronella, realizing his neglect, decided to take a lover. She found an old woman, a fake saint, who encouraged her, saying women should enjoy their youth. The old woman helped Peronella find lovers.

One evening, Pietro was to sup with a friend, Ercolano. Peronella invited a handsome young man. As they sat down to supper, Pietro unexpectedly returned. Peronella quickly hid her lover under a hen-coop in an adjoining shed, covering him with sacking. She then opened the door to Pietro, feigning anger at his early return and accusing him of neglecting her. Pietro explained that it was a holiday (San Galeone's Feast) and he had found no work. He then told her he had sold an old vat that cluttered the house for five florins.

Peronella, quick-witted, claimed she had already sold the vat for seven florins to a man who was currently inside, checking its soundness. Pietro was delighted. The lover, Giannello Strignario, hearing this, emerged from the vat, pretending to have just finished his inspection. He complained the vat was dirty and needed scraping. Pietro, eager to finalize the sale, agreed to clean it himself. While Pietro was inside the vat, scraping, Peronella, leaning into the vat's mouth to direct him, allowed Giannello to make love to her.

Meanwhile, Pietro recounted to his wife how Ercolano had discovered his wife's lover hidden in a cupboard due to sneezing from sulphur fumes. Peronella, feigning outrage at Ercolano's wife's infidelity, condemned such women to be burned. Just then, an ass belonging to Pietro's farm, having escaped its stable, stepped on Giannello's fingers, causing him to cry out. Pietro, hearing the noise, discovered Giannello under the hen-coop.

Pietro, enraged, confronted his wife, accusing her of hypocrisy. Peronella, seeing he had not physically harmed her, boldly defended herself, arguing that his neglect drove her to seek satisfaction elsewhere. She reminded him of his own preferences and that she was a woman with desires. Pietro, realizing he couldn't win an argument, and perhaps secretly pleased by the young man's presence, agreed to a truce. He asked them to sup. After supper, Pietro made an arrangement with his wife, implying he would share her lover. The next morning, Giannello was escorted away, leaving Pietro to live in a strange arrangement with his wife.

**Conclusion of Day the Fifth**
Dioneo's story, though deemed unseemly by some ladies, provoked much laughter, relieving the melancholy of the previous tales. Lauretta, her reign ended, crowned Emilia as queen, praising her beauty and urging her to match it with her actions. Emilia, blushing, accepted. She declared that for the next day, they would have no fixed theme, allowing everyone to discourse as they pleased, like oxen released from the yoke to graze freely. This was commended by all. They then enjoyed their usual evening activities. Pamfilo sang a song about the joy of secret love, which hinted at his own hidden passion. The king then dismissed them to rest.

**Day the Sixth**

**Introduction**
At dawn, the company walked in the dewy grass, discussing the previous day's stories. As the sun grew hot, they returned to the palace for breakfast and then sang and danced. After their rest, they reassembled by the fountain. As Queen Elisa was about to call for the first story, a loud clamor erupted from the kitchen. The seneschal reported an argument between Licisca and Tindaro. Elisa summoned them. Licisca, an older, boisterous woman, spoke first, complaining that Tindaro, a young man, dared to tell her that Sicofante's wife (a neighbor) had lost her virginity violently on her wedding night. Licisca vehemently denied this, claiming the wife had accepted her husband "in peace and to the great contentment of those within." She then launched into a tirade about women's sexual experiences, claiming she knew no woman who was a virgin on her wedding night and that wives always trick their husbands.

The ladies laughed uncontrollably. Elisa tried to silence Licisca, but she continued until she had finished. Elisa then turned to Dioneo, saying this matter was for his jurisdiction. Dioneo immediately ruled in Licisca's favor, declaring Tindaro an ass. Licisca, triumphant, continued to boast until Elisa, angrily, silenced her and sent her and Tindaro away. Elisa then called on Filomena to begin the day's stories.

**Story 1: Madam Oretta (Filomena)**
Filomena tells of Madam Oretta, a noble, well-bred, and well-spoken Florentine lady, wife of Messer Geri Spina. One day, while she was walking with a company of ladies and gentlemen in the countryside, one gentleman offered to "carry her a-horseback" a great part of the way with one of the finest stories in the world. Madam Oretta gladly accepted. The gentleman began a good story, but he told it so poorly, repeating words, correcting himself, and confusing names, that he ruined it. Madam Oretta, feeling sick from the tedious narration, finally interrupted him pleasantly, saying, "Sir, this horse of yours hath too hard a trot; wherefore I pray you be pleased to set me down." The gentleman, understanding her witty rebuke, laughed, changed the subject, and left the story unfinished.

**Story 2: Cisti the Baker (Pampinea)**
Pampinea tells of Cisti, a baker in Florence, a man of humble condition but noble spirit and great wealth, who owned the finest wines. Messer Geri Spina, a prominent citizen, often passed Cisti's bakehouse with papal ambassadors. Cisti, wishing to offer them his excellent white wine but deeming it unseemly to invite them directly, devised a plan. Every morning, he would place a pail of water, a pitcher of his wine, and two silver-bright beakers outside his door. As Messer Geri passed, Cisti would drink his wine with such relish that it would make anyone thirsty.

After two mornings, Messer Geri, intrigued, asked Cisti if the wine was good. Cisti invited him and the ambassadors to taste it. Cisti personally served them, washing the beakers and ensuring no servant tasted it. The wine was excellent, and Messer Geri and the ambassadors drank it almost daily. When the ambassadors were about to depart, Messer Geri hosted a magnificent banquet and invited Cisti, who declined. Messer Geri then sent a servant to Cisti for a flask of his wine. The servant, spitefully taking a large flagon, was told by Cisti, "My son, Messer Geri sent thee not to me." The servant returned, and Messer Geri, realizing the servant's intent, sent him back with a smaller, appropriate flask. Cisti then cheerfully filled it. That same day, Cisti sent a small cask of the wine to Messer Geri's house, explaining that he didn't want him to think it was common wine, and that he would no longer be his steward for it. Messer Geri greatly appreciated Cisti's gift and ever after held him in high regard.

**Story 3: Madam Nonna de' Pulci (Lauretta)**
Lauretta tells of Messer Antonio d'Orso, Bishop of Florence. A Catalan gentleman, Messer Dego della Ratta, marshal for King Robert, fell in love with a beautiful Florentine lady, the Bishop's niece. Knowing her husband was miserly, Messer Dego bribed him with 500 gilded silver coins to lie with his wife. The affair became public, shaming the husband. The Bishop, a discreet man, feigned ignorance.

One St. John's Day, as the Bishop and the Marshal rode, viewing ladies, the Bishop pointed out Madam Nonna de' Pulci, a fresh, fair, well-spoken, and high-spirited young woman. He jested, "Nonna, how deemest thou of this gallant? Thinkest thou thou couldst make a conquest of him?" Madam Nonna, feeling her honor impugned, quickly retorted, "Maybe, sir, he would not make a conquest of me; but, in any case, I should want good money." Both the Marshal (who had paid for sex with the Bishop's niece) and the Bishop (whose kinswoman had been dishonored for money) felt the sting of her words. They rode off, silent and ashamed.

**Story 4: Chichibio the Cook (Neifile)**
Neifile tells of Currado Gianfigliazzi, a noble, liberal, and magnificent Florentine citizen, who enjoyed hawking. One day, he caught a fat young crane and sent it to his Venetian cook, Chichibio, to be roasted for supper. As the crane cooked, Brunetta, a neighbor's wench Chichibio loved, came into the kitchen, smelled the savory bird, and demanded a thigh. Chichibio, singing, refused. Brunetta threatened to withhold her favors. To appease her, Chichibio cut off a thigh and gave it to her.

At supper, Currado and his guests noticed the crane was missing a thigh. Currado asked Chichibio what happened. Chichibio, without hesitation, replied, "Sir, cranes have but one thigh and one leg." Currado, enraged, insisted he had seen cranes with two. Chichibio maintained his lie, offering to show him a live, one-legged crane the next morning. Currado, unwilling to argue before guests, swore that if Chichibio was lying, he would punish him severely.

The next morning, Currado, still angry, took Chichibio to a watercourse where cranes gathered. Chichibio, terrified, saw a dozen cranes standing on one leg, as they do when sleeping. He pointed them out to Currado, saying, "Now, sir, if you look at those that stand yonder, you may very well see that I told you the truth yesternight, to wit, that cranes have but one thigh and one leg." Currado cried "Ho! Ho!" The cranes put down their other legs and flew away. Currado asked, "How sayst thou now, malapert knave that thou art? Deemest thou they have two legs?" Chichibio, flustered, quickly retorted, "Ay, sir; but you did not cry, 'Ho! Ho!' to yesternight's crane; had you cried thus, it would have put out the other thigh and the other leg, even as did those yonder." This witty reply so amused Currado that his anger turned to laughter, and Chichibio escaped punishment.

**Story 5: Messer Forese da Rabatta and Master Giotto (Pamfilo)**
Pamfilo tells of Messer Forese da Rabatta, a learned but ugly Florentine lawyer, and Master Giotto, the renowned painter, also not handsome. Both had country houses in Mugello. One summer day, returning to Florence, they met on the road, both on sorry cart-horses and poorly dressed. A sudden shower forced them to take shelter. Wishing to reach Florence by daylight, they borrowed old, rusty cloaks and hats from a husbandman and continued their journey, now drenched and muddy.

As they rode, Messer Forese, looking at Giotto's disheveled appearance, laughed and asked, "How sayst thou, Giotto? An there encountered us here a stranger who had never seen thee, thinkest thou he would believe thee to be, as thou art, the finest painter in the world?" Giotto immediately retorted, "Ay, sir, methinketh he might e'en believe it whenas, looking upon you, he should believe that you knew your A B C." Messer Forese, realizing his own equally poor appearance, understood he had been repaid "in his own coin."

**Story 6: Michele Scalza (Fiammetta)**
Fiammetta tells of Michele Scalza, a merry and agreeable Florentine, known for his stories. One day, with friends at Monte Ughi, a discussion arose about the oldest and best gentlemen in Florence. Various families were named. Scalza laughed and declared, "The best gentlemen and the oldest, not only of Florence, but of all the world or the Maremma, are the Cadgers [beggars],... upon which all the phisopholers [philosophers] and every one who knoweth them, as I do, are of accord." He offered to wager a supper on this, to be judged by Piero di Fiorentino.

Neri Mannini accepted the wager. Piero, the judge, asked Scalza to prove his claim. Scalza argued that the older something is, the nobler it is. He asserted that God made the Cadgers when he was first learning to draw, while other men were made after he had mastered his art. As proof, he pointed to the Cadgers' distorted and disproportionate faces (long, strait, broad, crooked noses, uneven eyes), comparing them to children's first drawings, while other men have well-composed faces. Thus, the Cadgers were more ancient and therefore nobler. Piero, Neri, and all present laughed, agreeing Scalza had won the supper, acknowledging the Cadgers as the noblest and most ancient gentlemen.

**Story 7: Madam Filippa (Filostrato)**
Filostrato tells of a cruel statute in Prato: any woman caught in adultery by her husband would be burned, like a prostitute. Madam Filippa, a noble and beautiful lady, was found by her husband, Rinaldo de' Pugliesi, in bed with her lover, Lazzerino de' Guazzagliotri. Rinaldo, enraged, refrained from killing them but accused his wife under the statute.

Madam Filippa, courageous, chose to appear in court and confess the truth rather than flee. Before the provost, she firmly admitted her affair, stating it was due to her great love for Lazzerino. She then argued that laws should be common to all and made with the consent of those they concern. This statute, she claimed, was unjust because it applied only to women, who could satisfy many, and no woman had consented to its creation. She then asked the provost to question her husband if she had ever denied him "entire commodity of myself" whenever he desired.

Rinaldo, without waiting for the provost, immediately confirmed that she had always granted him his every pleasure. Madam Filippa then retorted, "Then, my lord provost, if he have still taken of me that which was needful and pleasing to him, what, I ask you, was or am I to do with that which remaineth over and above his requirements? Should I cast it to the dogs? Was it not far better to gratify withal a gentleman who loveth me more than himself, than to leave it waste or spoil?" The crowd, hearing her comical question, laughed and cried out that she was right. At the provost's instance, they modified the statute to apply only to women who sold their favors for money. Rinaldo, shamed, left the court, and Madam Filippa returned home in triumph.

**Story 8: Fresco (Emilia)**
Emilia tells of Fresco da Celatico and his niece, Ciesca, a beautiful but arrogant and disagreeable woman who constantly found fault with everyone and everything. She was so prideful that she made wry faces as if everyone she met stank. One day, she returned home early, puffing and blowing. Fresco asked why she was home so soon on a holiday. Ciesca replied that there were too many disagreeable people in the city, and she found it irksome to see them. Fresco, displeased by her airs, retorted, "My lass, if disagreeable folk be so distasteful to thee as thou sayest, never mirror thyself in the glass, so thou wouldst live merry." Ciesca, too foolish to understand his meaning, insisted she would mirror herself like other women, remaining in her folly.

**Story 9: Guido Cavalcanti (Neifile)**
Neifile tells of Guido Cavalcanti, a noble, witty, and learned Florentine gentleman, who was often engrossed in abstract philosophical speculations. He was rumored to be an Epicurean, seeking to prove that God did not exist. Messer Betto Brunelleschi and his company, who enjoyed banquets and jousts, tried to recruit Guido, but he avoided them. One day, as Guido walked alone among the marble tombs near San Giovanni, Messer Betto and his company, on horseback, rode up to him and, to tease him, asked, "Guido, thou refusest to be of our company; but, harkye, whenas thou shalt have found that God is not, what wilt thou have accomplished?"

Guido, seeing himself surrounded, quickly replied, "Gentlemen, you may say what you will to me in your own house." He then nimbly sprang onto one of the tombs and made his escape. The gentlemen were confused, believing his answer meant nothing, as they were in a public place. But Messer Betto, a subtle man, explained, "It is you who are the crackbrains, if you have not apprehended him. He hath courteously and in a few words given us the sharpest rebuke in the world; for that, an you consider aright, these tombs are the houses of the dead, seeing they are laid and abide therein, and these, saith he, are our house, meaning thus to show us that we and other foolish and unlettered men are, compared with him and other men of learning, worse than dead folk; wherefore, being here, we are in our own house." They all understood and were ashamed, never bothering Guido again.

**Story 10: Fra Cipolla (Dioneo)**
Dioneo tells of Fra Cipolla, a friar of St. Anthony, who annually visited Certaldo to collect alms. He was a small, red-haired, merry, and witty man, a great talker, though unlearned. He was popular in the village. One Sunday, he announced to the villagers that after none, he would preach and show them a holy relic he brought from the Holy Land: "one of the Angel Gabriel's feathers, which remained in the Virgin Mary's chamber, whenas he came to announce to her in Nazareth."

Two roguish young men, Giovanni del Bragioniera and Biagio Pizzini, friends of the friar, decided to play a trick. They learned he was dining in the burgh. While his servant, Guccio Balena (a lazy, gluttonous, ill-mannered, and womanizing knave), was distracted by a cookmaid, Giovanni searched Fra Cipolla's saddle-bags. He found a small casket containing a parrot's tail-feather, which he correctly guessed was the "angel's feather." He took the feather, filled the casket with coals he found nearby, and replaced it, leaving everything as he found it.

After dinner, Fra Cipolla, unaware of the trick, sent Guccio for his bells and saddle-bags. Guccio, still full from the kitchen, arrived breathless. Fra Cipolla began his sermon, then, with great solemnity, prepared to reveal the feather. He praised the Angel Gabriel and his relic, then opened the casket to find it full of coals. Without changing expression, he raised his hands to heaven and, to the astonishment of the crowd, launched into an elaborate, fantastical tale. He claimed he had been sent to the East to find the "Privileges of Porcellana" and had traveled through many invented lands (Borgo de' Greci, Algarve, Baldacca, Parione, Sardinia, Truffia, Buffia, Menzogna, Abruzzi, Mountains of the Bachi, India Pastinaca), seeing impossible things (hedge-bills fly, Maso del Saggio selling walnut shells). He claimed to have met the "venerable father my lord Blamemenot Anitpleaseyou, the very worshipful Patriarch of Jerusalem," who showed him countless relics (finger of the Holy Ghost, forelock of a seraph, Cherubim's nail, Verbum Caro's rib, vestments of Holy Catholic Faith, rays of the star of the Magi, sweat of St. Michael, jawbone of Death of St. Lazarus). In exchange for some "Steeps of Monte Morello" and "chapters of the Caprezio," the Patriarch gave him a tooth of the Holy Rood, the sound of Solomon's Temple bells in a vial, the Angel Gabriel's feather, and coals from St. Lawrence's martyrdom.

He explained that he carried the feather in one casket and the coals in another, but they were so similar he had accidentally brought the wrong one. He declared it God's will, as St. Lawrence's feast day was near, so he could show them the blessed coals. He then offered to mark anyone with the coals, promising fire would not touch them for a year. The simple crowd, impressed, offered him money to be marked. Fra Cipolla made many crosses on their clothes, claiming the coals miraculously regenerated. Thus, by his quick wit, he escaped shame and profited from the deception. Giovanni and Biagio, who witnessed the entire performance, laughed until their jaws ached. They later returned the feather to him.

**Conclusion of Day the Sixth**
Dioneo's story caused much laughter. Elisa, her reign ended, crowned Dioneo as king, challenging him to govern the ladies well. Dioneo accepted, promising to ensure their enjoyment. He then set the theme for the seventh day: "OF THE TRICKS WHICH OR FOR LOVE OR FOR THEIR OWN PRESERVATION WOMEN HAVE HERETOFORE PLAYED THEIR HUSBANDS WITH OR WITHOUT THE LATTER'S COGNIZANCE THEREOF." Some ladies objected, finding the theme unseemly, but Dioneo defended it, arguing that in times of plague, with laws silent, freedom of discourse was permitted for diversion, and their virtue was beyond reproach. He also suggested that shying away from such topics might imply guilt. The ladies agreed. They then went to the Ladies' Valley, a beautiful, secluded spot with a clear stream and lakelet. They bathed naked, unseen, and then returned to the palace for supper. Pamfilo sang a song about his secret love, which was noted by the company. The king dismissed them to rest.

**Day the Seventh**

**Introduction**
At dawn, the seneschal went to the Ladies' Valley to prepare it. The king and company followed, enjoying the birdsong. They admired the valley's beauty, then had breakfast. They sang, then rested in beds prepared in the valley. After a while, they reassembled by the lake for storytelling. The king bade Emilia begin.

**Story 1: Gianni Lotteringhi (Emilia)**
Emilia tells of Gianni Lotteringhi, a simple-minded wool-comber in Florence, who was often chosen as captain of the Laudsingers and held other minor offices due to his wealth and donations to the clergy. He cherished various pious orisons taught by the friars. His discreet and beautiful wife, Mistress Tessa, was having an affair with Federigo di Neri Pegolotti. They had a secret signal system: an ass's skull on a vine pole in her garden. If the muzzle faced Florence, Federigo could come that evening; if towards Fiesole, Gianni was home. If the door was shut, he was to knock thrice.

One night, Federigo was to sup with Tessa, who had prepared two fat capons. Gianni, unexpectedly, returned late. Tessa, chagrined, hid the capons, eggs, and wine in the garden under a peach tree. Gianni and Tessa went to bed. Federigo arrived and knocked twice. Gianni heard it and nudged Tessa, who feigned awakening. She told him it was a "phantom" that had been frightening her. Gianni, believing his orisons (Te Lucis, Intemerata) protected them, was not afraid. Tessa, fearing Federigo might suspect something, insisted they "exorcise" it.

She led Gianni to the door and instructed him to spit when she told him. She then began a conjuration: "Phantom, phantom that goest by night, with tail upright thou cam'st to us; now get thee gone with tail upright. Begone into the garden to the foot of the great peach tree; there shalt thou find an anointed twice-anointed one [fat capon] and an hundred turds of my sitting hen [eggs]; set thy mouth to the flagon and get thee gone again and do thou no hurt to my Gianni nor to me." Gianni spat. Federigo, outside, understood the message and, despite his vexation, was amused. He waited for Gianni to spit again, then said under his breath, "[Would it were] thy teeth!"

Tessa and Gianni returned to bed. Federigo went to the garden, found the food and wine, and supped at his ease. He later shared a laugh with Tessa about the conjuration. Emilia mentions a variant where a husbandman accidentally turned the ass's skull, and another where the story happened to Gianni di Nello, another simpleton. She concludes that the orisons are very effective in such cases.

**Story 2: Peronella (Filostrato)**
Filostrato tells of Peronella, a beautiful young woman in Naples, wife of a poor mason. She took a lover, Giannello Strignario. They arranged for Giannello to visit her when her husband left for work. One morning, Giannello was with Peronella when her husband unexpectedly returned. Peronella quickly hid Giannello in a large vat in the shed. She then opened the door to her husband, feigning anger, accusing him of returning early and neglecting their livelihood.

The husband explained it was a holiday and he had sold the old vat, which cluttered the house, for five florins. Peronella, quick-witted, claimed she had already sold it for seven florins to a man who was currently inside, inspecting its soundness. The husband was pleased. Giannello, overhearing, emerged from the vat, pretending to have just finished his inspection. He complained the vat was dirty and needed scraping. The husband, eager for the seven florins, agreed to clean it. While he was inside the vat, scraping, Peronella, leaning into the vat's mouth to direct him, allowed Giannello to make love to her. When both tasks were completed, Giannello paid the husband seven florins and had the vat carried to his house.

**Story 3: Fra Rinaldo (Elisa)**
Elisa tells of Rinaldo, a noble young man in Siena, who loved his beautiful neighbor, Madam Agnesa, wife of a rich man. To gain access, he became godfather to her child, thus becoming her "gossip." Later, Rinaldo became a friar, but his love for Agnesa rekindled. He began to visit her frequently, pressing his suit. Agnesa, initially hesitant due to their gossip-relationship, eventually yielded, convinced by Rinaldo's argument that he, being less akin to her child than her husband, could lie with her just as her husband did. They continued their affair discreetly.

One day, Rinaldo was with Agnesa in her bedchamber, having sent her maid and his comrade to the pigeon-loft. Agnesa's husband unexpectedly returned and knocked at the door. Agnesa, terrified, told Rinaldo, who was in his waistcoat, that they were discovered. Agnesa, seizing an idea, told Rinaldo to dress, take their child, and listen to her. She then opened the door to her husband, feigning great joy, claiming Fra Rinaldo had come just in time to save their child from a sudden fainting fit caused by "worms." She said Rinaldo was conjuring the worms and that only the mother could be present.

The simple husband believed her. Rinaldo, having dressed and taken the child, confirmed the story, claiming the child was now cured. The husband, overjoyed, thanked Rinaldo. Rinaldo's comrade, who had been with the maid in the pigeon-loft, also returned, claiming to have finished his orisons. The husband, completely fooled, entertained them with wine and confections. He later made a waxen image of his child and hung it in the church as an ex-voto.

**Story 4: Tofano (Lauretta)**
Lauretta tells of Tofano, a rich but jealous man in Arezzo, and his beautiful wife, Ghita. Tofano's jealousy, being unfounded, annoyed Ghita, who decided to give him reason for it. She found a lover and, discovering Tofano enjoyed drinking, encouraged him to get drunk. When he was intoxicated, she would put him to bed and meet her lover. She grew so confident that she sometimes spent the night at her lover's house.

One evening, Tofano, suspecting her, feigned extreme drunkenness. Ghita, believing him, put him to bed and went to her lover's house. Tofano immediately arose, locked the doors from within, and waited at the window. When Ghita returned at midnight, she found herself locked out. Tofano confronted her, saying she couldn't re-enter and he would expose her. Ghita pleaded, claiming she was with a neighbor. Tofano remained firm. Ghita then threatened to throw herself into a nearby well, knowing he would be blamed for her death.

Tofano, unmoved, told her to leave her distaff. Ghita took a large stone, cried, "God pardon me!" and dropped it into the well. Tofano, believing she had jumped, rushed out with a bucket and rope to save her. Ghita, who had hidden near the door, slipped inside and locked him out. She then went to the window and taunted him, "You should water your wine, whenas you drink it, and not after and by night." Tofano, realizing he was tricked, demanded entry. Ghita, now shouting, refused, threatening to expose his late-night returns. Neighbors, awakened by the commotion, blamed Tofano. Ghita's kinsfolk arrived, beat Tofano, and took Ghita home. Tofano, seeing his jealousy had backfired, made peace with his wife, promising never to be jealous again and giving her leave to do as she pleased, provided she was discreet.

**Story 5: A Jealous Husband (Fiammetta)**
Fiammetta tells of a rich merchant in Rimini who was excessively jealous of his beautiful wife without cause. He kept her confined, not allowing her out or even to look from a window. The wife, feeling unjustly suspected, resolved to give him reason for his jealousy. She noticed a handsome young man in the adjoining house. She found a small crack in the wall between their bedchambers and, through pebbles and soft calls, managed to communicate with him. He enlarged the hole, and they exchanged words and touched hands, but could go no further due to the husband's vigilance.

As Christmas approached, the wife asked her husband for permission to go to church for confession and communion. He agreed, but only to their parish chapel, early, and to their chaplain or a priest he appointed, then straight home. The wife suspected his plan. On Christmas morning, she went to church. Her husband, having arranged with the chaplain, disguised himself as a priest with a large cowl and sat in the choir. The chaplain sent him to hear her confession. The wife, recognizing him despite his disguise and muffled voice, decided to give him what he sought.

She confessed to being married but in love with a priest who visited her every night. She claimed he knew a charm that made her husband fall asleep and opened all doors. The jealous husband, enraged, almost ended the confession but wanted to know more. He rebuked her, but she claimed she loved the priest too much to stop. He offered to pray for her and send a clerk to check on her progress. She refused to have anyone sent to her house, fearing her husband's jealousy.

The husband, bursting with rage, returned home. That night, he told his wife he would be away and instructed her to lock all doors. The wife, however, signaled her lover through the wall, telling him her husband would be watching the street door, so he should come by the roof. The lover agreed. The husband hid by the street door all night, cold and supperless, waiting for the priest. The lover entered by the roof, and he and the wife made love.

In the morning, the husband, exhausted, returned to his room. He sent a boy (as the priest's clerk) to ask his wife if the "priest" had visited. She replied he hadn't. Finally, the husband confronted her, demanding to know the priest's identity. She laughed, revealing she knew he was the disguised priest. She explained that his jealousy had blinded him, and his "priest" was himself, his "charms" his own access, and his nightly visits were his own presence. She concluded that if she ever wanted to cuckold him, she could do so even if he had a hundred eyes. The husband, realizing he was completely fooled, gave up his jealousy. The wife, now with license, brought her lover in through the door and continued their affair discreetly.

**Story 6: Madam Isabella (Pampinea)**
Pampinea tells of Madam Isabella, a noble and beautiful Florentine lady, wife of a worthy gentleman. She took a lover, Leonetto, a well-bred young man. They enjoyed their secret love. Isabella was also pursued by Messer Lambertuccio, a powerful gentleman whom she disliked but feared. She reluctantly yielded to his threats.

One summer day, Isabella was at her country estate, her husband away. She sent for Leonetto. While they were together, her maid announced Messer Lambertuccio's arrival. Isabella was terrified. She hid Leonetto behind the bed curtains. Lambertuccio entered, embraced and kissed her, and they went to her chamber. As they were making love, the maid announced the unexpected return of Isabella's husband.

Isabella, realizing she had two men in the house and Lambertuccio's horse was visible in the courtyard, thought quickly. She told Lambertuccio to take his dagger, rush downstairs with an angry face, and leave, shouting, "I vow to God that I will take him elsewhere." If her husband questioned him, he was to say nothing else. Lambertuccio, fearing for his life, obeyed. The husband, dismounting, saw Lambertuccio rush out, shouting threats. He asked what was happening. Lambertuccio, mounting his horse, only repeated, "Cock's body, I shall find him again otherwhere," and rode off.

The husband found Isabella at the stairhead, disheveled and fearful. She claimed an unknown young man had fled into her chamber, pursued by Lambertuccio, and she had prevented Lambertuccio from entering. The husband praised her for preventing murder in their house. He then asked where the young man was. Leonetto, who had heard everything, emerged, trembling. He claimed Lambertuccio had attacked him on the road for no reason. The husband, believing him, promised to escort him home safely. After supper, the husband took Leonetto home. Leonetto then discreetly met Lambertuccio and explained the situation. The husband never learned of his wife's deception.

**Story 7: Lodovico (Filomena)**
Filomena tells of Lodovico, a Florentine gentleman who became rich as a merchant in Paris. He was sent to serve the King of France. He heard travelers praise Madam Beatrice, wife of Messer Egano de' Gulluzzi of Bologna, as the most beautiful lady. Lodovico, instantly enamored, feigned a pilgrimage to the Holy Sepulchre to go to Bologna. There, he saw Beatrice and fell deeply in love. He resolved to win her love. He disguised himself as a servant, Anichino, and took service with Messer Egano, quickly becoming his most trusted man.

One day, while Egano was fowling, Anichino played chess with Beatrice. When they were alone, he sighed. Beatrice, curious, asked the cause. Anichino, after feigning reluctance, confessed his true identity, his love for her, and why he had become Egano's servant. He begged her to have compassion. Beatrice, moved by his words and his worth, returned his love, promising to meet him that night. She instructed him to come to her chamber at midnight, where she would leave the door open.

That night, Egano, tired from fowling, went to bed early. Beatrice left her chamber door open. Anichino entered, closed the door, and went to her bed. As he touched her, she took his hand and, turning in bed, woke Egano. She then asked Egano whom he considered his most trusted servant. Egano replied Anichino. Anichino, hearing this, was terrified, thinking she would expose him. Beatrice then told Egano that Anichino had tried to seduce her that day and had arranged to meet her in the garden by the pine tree that night. She suggested Egano, disguised in her gown and veil, go in her place to test Anichino's fidelity.

Egano, eager to test Anichino, dressed in his wife's clothes and went to the garden. As soon as he left, Beatrice locked the door and returned to bed with Anichino, who was overjoyed by her cleverness. They made love. After a while, Beatrice told Anichino to take a stout cudgel, go to the garden, and beat Egano (still disguised as her) while pretending to scold her for her supposed infidelity. Anichino obeyed, beating Egano severely. Egano fled back to the chamber, complaining of the beating. Beatrice, feigning sympathy, said Anichino had tested her with words and him with deeds, proving his loyalty. Egano, convinced, believed he had the truest wife and most loyal servant. Anichino and Beatrice continued their affair discreetly.

**Story 8: A Man Waxeth Jealous (Neifile)**
Neifile tells of Arriguccio Berlinghieri, a rich Florentine merchant, who married the noble Madam Sismonda. Arriguccio, often away on business, became fiercely jealous. He would not sleep until he felt Sismonda in bed and slept soundly. Sismonda, unhappy, took a lover, Ruberto. To meet him, she devised a system: she would tie a twine to her great toe, extending it out her window to the street. Ruberto would pull it at midnight. If she let go, her husband was asleep; if she held it, he was awake.

One night, Arriguccio, stretching his foot, felt the twine. He realized the trick, cut the twine from her toe, and tied it to his own. Ruberto pulled, and Arriguccio, thinking it was a signal, rushed out armed to catch the lover. Ruberto, hearing the loud opening of the door, realized it was Arriguccio and fled. Arriguccio pursued him, and they fought.

Meanwhile, Sismonda awoke, found the twine cut, and knew she was discovered. She quickly called her maid and persuaded her to take her place in the bed, enduring any beating from Arriguccio. She put out the light and hid. Arriguccio, returning from the fight (which had attracted neighbors), entered the dark chamber, found the maid, whom he thought was Sismonda, and beat her severely, cutting off her hair, while she cried for mercy. He then locked her in and went to Sismonda's brothers to expose her.

Sismonda, hearing him leave, comforted the maid and rewarded her. She then made the bed, dressed, and sat sewing at the stairhead, feigning innocence. Arriguccio arrived with Sismonda's three brothers and mother. He recounted his discovery of the twine, the pursuit, the beating, and presented the maid's hair as proof. The brothers, enraged, followed him home. Sismonda, seeing them, greeted them calmly. Her brothers, seeing her composed and unharmed, began to doubt Arriguccio. He insisted he had beaten her, but she denied it, showing her unblemished face and unshorn hair.

Sismonda then accused Arriguccio of being a drunken philanderer, claiming he must have gone to bed with a "trull" and, waking, imagined he was beating her. Her mother, furious at Arriguccio's accusations, supported Sismonda, calling him a "four-farthing huckster" unworthy of her daughter. The brothers, convinced Arriguccio was drunk and mistaken, severely rebuked him, warning him never to bring such news again. Arriguccio, utterly confused, left his wife in peace. Sismonda, by her wit, not only escaped peril but secured her freedom for future affairs.

**Story 9: Lydia (Pamfilo)**
Pamfilo tells of Nicostratus, a nobleman in Argos, whose young and spirited wife, Lydia, fell in love with his handsome and trusted servant, Pyrrhus. Pyrrhus, initially unaware or unwilling, seemed indifferent. Lydia, distraught, confided in her chamberwoman, Lusca, who conveyed her mistress's fervent love to Pyrrhus. Pyrrhus, fearing a trick, demanded three proofs of her love: she must kill Nicostratus's favorite hawk in his presence, send him a lock of her husband's beard, and one of his best teeth. Lydia, though finding these hard, agreed, adding she would also make love to him in Nicostratus's presence and make her husband believe it was not real.

First, at a dinner party, Lydia deliberately killed Nicostratus's hawk, claiming it stole his time from her. The guests, amused, turned Nicostratus's anger into laughter. Pyrrhus, witnessing this, was encouraged. Second, while toying with Nicostratus, she playfully pulled out a lock of his beard, claiming it was revenge for him pulling her hair. She sent the beard to Pyrrhus. Third, she convinced Nicostratus that he had bad breath due to a rotten tooth. She then offered to extract it herself, sending everyone else away. With Lusca's help, she painfully extracted one of his teeth, which she sent to Pyrrhus.

Now convinced, Pyrrhus was ready. Lydia, feigning illness, asked Nicostratus and Pyrrhus to take her to the garden. They sat under a pear tree. Lydia asked Pyrrhus to climb the tree for pears. As he threw down pears, Pyrrhus began to shout, "How now, my lord! What is this you do? And you, madam, are you not ashamed to suffer it in my presence?" He claimed to see Nicostratus making love to Lydia. Nicostratus was astonished, thinking Pyrrhus was raving. Lydia feigned indignation, suggesting the tree was enchanted. Nicostratus, to prove it, climbed the tree. As soon as he was up, Lydia and Pyrrhus made love below. Nicostratus, seeing them, cried out. The lovers, seeing him descend, quickly resumed their innocent positions.

Nicostratus, enraged, confronted them. Pyrrhus, feigning confusion, claimed that just as Nicostratus had seen falsely from the tree, he himself must have seen falsely earlier. Lydia feigned fury, saying she would never be so foolish as to commit adultery in front of him. Nicostratus, convinced by their arguments that the tree caused hallucinations, ordered it cut down. Pyrrhus readily complied. Lydia, feigning forgiveness, reconciled with her husband. Pyrrhus and Lydia continued their affair more easily.

**Story 10: Two Siennese (Dioneo)**
Dioneo tells of two Siennese friends, Tingoccio Mini and Meuccio di Tura, who made a pact: the first to die would return to tell the other about the afterlife. Tingoccio became godfather to Mistress Mita's child, and then, despite the gossip-relationship, fell in love with her. Meuccio also loved her but kept it secret. Tingoccio and Mistress Mita became lovers. Meuccio, aware of their affair, feigned ignorance, hoping to eventually have her himself.

Tingoccio, from his excessive lovemaking with his gossip, fell ill and died. Three days later, his ghost appeared to Meuccio, fulfilling their pact. Meuccio, initially frightened, asked if Tingoccio was damned. Tingoccio said he was in torment for his sins but not damned. He described the punishments for various sins. Meuccio then asked if there was anything he could do for him (masses, prayers, alms). Tingoccio agreed. Meuccio then asked about the punishment for lying with a gossip. Tingoccio replied that in the afterlife, "no manner of account [is] taken of gossips." Hearing this, Meuccio was greatly relieved and decided to pursue his own affair with Mistress Mita without guilt.

**Conclusion of Day the Seventh**
Dioneo's story caused much laughter, especially the part about "no account is taken of gossips." Lauretta, her reign ended, crowned Emilia as queen. Emilia, after making arrangements, announced that for the next day, there would be no fixed theme, allowing everyone to tell stories as they pleased. She explained that after many days of restricted themes, it was good to have a "truant" day. The company approved. The ladies then visited the "Ladies' Valley" again, bathing naked in the lakelet. The young men, hearing of its beauty, visited it after supper. Pamfilo sang a song about his secret love, which was noted by the company. The queen then dismissed them to rest.

**Day the Eighth**

**Introduction**
On Sunday morning, the company arose, walked in the dewy grass, and visited a nearby church for divine service. They returned for breakfast, then sang and danced. After their rest, they reassembled by the fountain. Queen Neifile (this seems to be a mistake in the text, as Emilia was crowned queen at the end of Day 7, and the introduction for Day 8 states "under the governance of Elisa is discoursed...". However, the text then says "Neifile, by her commandment, began thus." I will follow the text as written, noting the discrepancy in the summary.) began the day's stories.

**Story 1: Gulfardo (Neifile)**
Neifile tells of Gulfardo, a German soldier in Milan, known for his loyalty and prompt repayment of debts. He fell in love with Madam Ambruogia, wife of a rich merchant, Guasparruolo Cagastraccio, a friend of his. Gulfardo discreetly pursued her. The lady, after some negotiation, agreed to his advances if he kept it secret and gave her 200 gold florins for a personal need.

Gulfardo, indignant at her greed, decided to trick her. He told her he would gladly give her the money and would bring it when he came to her, with a trusted comrade as a witness. The lady, pleased, arranged a meeting when her husband was away. Gulfardo then went to Guasparruolo and borrowed 200 florins at his usual low interest. A few days later, Guasparruolo went to Genoa. Gulfardo, with his comrade, went to Ambruogia's house and, in his comrade's presence, gave her the 200 florins, saying, "Madam, take these monies and give them to your husband, whenas he shall be returned." Ambruogia, thinking he did this to hide the payment from his friend, counted them and put them away, then took Gulfardo to her chamber. They made love many times before her husband returned.

When Guasparruolo came back, Gulfardo, again with his comrade, approached him in his wife's presence. Gulfardo stated he no longer needed the 200 florins Guasparruolo had lent him and had returned them to his wife. Guasparruolo asked his wife, who, seeing the witness, could not deny it. She confirmed she had the money. Guasparruolo was satisfied. Gulfardo left. The lady, realizing she had been tricked, had to give her husband the money, having received nothing for her favors. Thus, Gulfardo enjoyed his "sordid mistress without cost."

**Story 2: The Parish Priest of Varlungo (Pamfilo)**
Pamfilo tells of a lusty priest in Varlungo who was enamored of Mistress Belcolore, a jolly, buxom country woman. He pursued her with gifts of garlic, peascods, and chives. One day, he met Belcolore's husband, Bentivegna, who was going to Florence. The priest, seeing his opportunity, went to Belcolore's house. He confessed his love, and she, feigning coyness, asked if priests did such things. He assured her they did, and better, promising it would be "shrewdly to thy profit." She, calling priests stingy, asked what profit. He offered shoes, a head-lace, or a waistband. She refused, saying she had enough. She then proposed a deal: if he lent her five crowns to redeem her watchet gown and Sunday girdle from pawn, she would do his will.

The priest claimed not to have the money on him. Belcolore, suspicious, insisted he go get it. Fearing he would lose the opportunity, the priest offered his blue-cloth cloak as a pledge. Belcolore, after some haggling about its value, took the cloak. They then went to the barn, where they made love. The priest, after taking his leave, realized the cloak was worth more than five crowns. He devised a plan to get it back.

The next day, a holiday, he sent a boy to Belcolore, asking to borrow her stone mortar to make sauce for guests. Belcolore sent it. Later, while Bentivegna and Belcolore were at dinner, the priest sent his clerk to return the mortar and demand the cloak back as a "token." Bentivegna, angered that his wife had taken a pledge from the priest, ordered her to return it immediately. Belcolore, grumbling, gave the cloak to the clerk, telling him to tell the priest she would never again pound sauce in her mortar. The clerk reported this. The priest, laughing, sent back a message: if she wouldn't lend her mortar, he wouldn't lend his pestle, and they would be "quits." Belcolore bore a grudge but eventually made peace with him over must and roast chestnuts. The priest replaced her tabret's parchment and added hawk's bells, which she accepted in lieu of the five crowns.

**Story 3: Calandrino, Bruno, and Buffalmacco (Heliotrope) (Elisa)**
Elisa tells another story of Calandrino, Bruno, and Buffalmacco. Maso del Saggio, a witty young man, decided to play a trick on the simple-witted painter Calandrino. In the church of San Giovanni, Maso and a friend, pretending not to see Calandrino, discussed the virtues of stones. Maso claimed that in Bengodi (a fantastical land of plenty) there was a mountain of grated Parmesan cheese where people cooked macaroni and ravioli in capon broth, throwing them down for others to catch. Calandrino, intrigued, asked about the capons, and Maso said the Basques ate them. Calandrino, believing this, asked if such wonder-working stones could be found locally.

Maso then spoke of the "Heliotrope," a black stone found in the Mugnone river, which made its bearer invisible. Calandrino, excited, sought out Bruno and Buffalmacco, telling them of the stone and his plan to become rich by stealing money from exchangers. Bruno and Buffalmacco, amused, feigned interest. They agreed to search for it the following Sunday, when there would be fewer people about and the black stones would be easier to distinguish. Calandrino, impatient, awaited Sunday.

On Sunday morning, they went to the Mugnone. Calandrino, eager, picked up every black stone he saw, stuffing them into his bosom and the folds of his gown. When he was heavily laden, Bruno and Buffalmacco, pretending not to see him, began to call out, "Where is Calandrino?" They then accused him of abandoning them to go home for dinner, scoffing at the idea of finding such a stone. Calandrino, believing the heliotrope was working, remained silent and began walking home, laden with stones. As he walked, Bruno and Buffalmacco, still pretending not to see him, threw stones at his shins and back, saying they would make him remember the trick.

At the San Gallo gate, the customs officers, forewarned by Bruno and Buffalmacco, feigned not to see Calandrino, laughing heartily. Calandrino reached home, where his wife, Mistress Tessa, scolded him for being late for dinner. Calandrino, realizing he was visible, was furious. He accused his wife of "undoing" him (making the stone lose its power) and beat her severely. Bruno and Buffalmacco arrived, feigning concern. Calandrino, still angry, explained that his wife's presence had ruined the heliotrope's magic. The two friends pretended to believe him, but blamed him for not warning his wife. They then "made peace" between him and his bruised wife, leaving him disconsolate with a house full of stones.

**Story 4: The Rector of Fiesole (Emilia)**
Emilia tells of a rector of Fiesole who fell in love with Madam Piccarda, a noble widow. The rector, old in years but young in wit, was arrogant and ill-mannered. Piccarda hated him but, to rid herself of his persistent solicitations, consulted her brothers. With their permission, she devised a plan. She feigned to yield to the rector's advances, agreeing to meet him in her dark bedchamber that evening, warning him that her brothers slept nearby and he must be silent.

Piccarda had a very ugly, crooked, and squinting maidservant named Ciutazza. She bribed Ciutazza with a new shift to lie in her bed and embrace the rector, but to remain silent. That night, the rector arrived, entered the dark chamber, and lay with Ciutazza, believing her to be Piccarda. Meanwhile, Piccarda's brothers, as arranged, went to the main square. By chance, the bishop, wanting to drink with them, encountered them and returned to their house. The brothers then led the bishop and others to Piccarda's chamber. The rector, who had fallen asleep with Ciutazza, awoke to the light and the crowd. Ashamed, he hid his head. The bishop rebuked him, making him reveal his companion. The rector, realizing the trick, was mortified. He was sent home under guard and forced to do penance. The bishop, learning the full story, commended Piccarda and her brothers for their cleverness. The rector suffered public humiliation and was mocked by children, remaining tormented for a long time. Ciutazza, meanwhile, got her shift and a merry night.

**Story 5: Three Young Men and a Marchegan Judge (Filostrato)**
Filostrato tells of Maso del Saggio and his two friends, Ribi and Matteuzzo, who were known for their mad humor. They observed a Marchegan judge, Messer Niccola da San Lepidio, who had come to Florence for the Provost. The judge was a comical figure, poorly dressed, with an inkhorn at his girdle, and breeches that came halfway down his legs. Maso noticed that the judge's bench was constructed so that one could easily pass underneath and reach through cracks in the floorboards.

Maso proposed a trick: they would pull down the judge's breeches while he was on the bench. The friends agreed. The next morning, in a crowded court, Matteuzzo crept under the bench. Maso and Ribi approached the judge, each grabbing a skirt of his gown, and began a loud, fake dispute about stolen saddle-bags and boothose, accusing each other and demanding justice. The judge stood up and leaned forward to hear them better. Matteuzzo, seizing the opportunity, grabbed Messer Niccola's breeches and pulled them down. The breeches, being loose, came down easily. The judge, confused, tried to sit and cover himself, but Maso and Ribi held him, continuing their loud argument. Matteuzzo then slipped away. Maso and Ribi, having achieved their goal, also fled. The judge, realizing his humiliation, swore to find out if it was customary in Florence to pull down judges' breeches. The Provost, informed of the prank, was told it was a Florentine way of showing that he had brought incompetent judges. He decided to keep silent to avoid further shame.

**Story 6: Bruno and Buffalmacco (Pig) (Filomena)**
Filomena tells another story of Calandrino, Bruno, and Buffalmacco. Calandrino had a pig from his farm, which he and his wife usually salted. One year, his wife was ill, so he went alone. Bruno and Buffalmacco, staying with a priest friend nearby, saw the pig and decided to steal it. They tried to convince Calandrino to sell it and tell his wife it was stolen, but he refused. They then plotted to steal it that night.

They took Calandrino to the tavern with the priest, where Bruno made sure Calandrino drank heavily, paying for everything. Calandrino, easily fuddled, went home, leaving his door open, and fell asleep. Bruno and Buffalmacco entered, took the pig, and carried it to the priest's house. The next morning, Calandrino discovered his pig missing and his door open. He made a great outcry. Bruno and Buffalmacco arrived, feigning surprise. Bruno subtly suggested Calandrino was lying to his wife. Calandrino, distraught, insisted the pig was stolen.

Buffalmacco proposed an ordeal by bread and cheese to find the thief among the neighbors. Bruno suggested ginger boluses and good wine instead, as a less suspicious method. Calandrino, desperate, gave Bruno money to buy the ingredients. Bruno bought ginger boluses and secretly prepared two dog-balls with aloes, covering them with sugar like the others, and marking them. He returned, and they arranged for Calandrino to invite his suspicious neighbors to drink the next morning.

The next day, Calandrino gathered his neighbors. Bruno explained the ordeal: whoever swallowed a bolus easily was innocent; whoever found it bitter and spat it out was the thief. He gave each person a bolus, and when he came to Calandrino, he gave him one of the aloes-laced ones. Calandrino immediately spat it out. Bruno gave him another, which he also spat out, weeping from the bitterness. Everyone concluded Calandrino had stolen his own pig.

After everyone left, Bruno and Buffalmacco accused Calandrino of stealing the pig and lying. They claimed he had a mistress to whom he gave his money and the pig. They demanded two pairs of capons, threatening to tell his wife. Calandrino, not wanting more trouble with his wife, gave them the capons. They salted the pig and took the capons to Florence, leaving Calandrino to lament his losses.

**Story 7: A Scholar and a Widow Lady (Pampinea)**
Pampinea tells of Elena, a beautiful, haughty, and wealthy widow in Florence, who had a lover. Rinieri, a learned scholar returned from Paris, fell passionately in love with her. Elena, vain, encouraged his attention, believing it enhanced her beauty. She accepted his letters and gifts but gave him only vague promises. To prove to her lover (who was growing jealous) that Rinieri was no threat, she finally promised Rinieri a rendezvous on Christmas Eve, telling him to wait in her courtyard.

It had snowed heavily. Rinieri waited in the cold courtyard. Elena, after supping with her lover, went to a lattice with him to watch Rinieri. Her maid told Rinieri that Elena's brother was visiting, delaying her. Rinieri, believing her, patiently waited. Elena and her lover mocked him. Near midnight, Elena and her lover watched Rinieri dancing in the snow to keep warm. Elena then called to Rinieri from the door, still feigning her brother's presence, telling him to wait longer and make a fire when he came in. She and her lover returned to bed, laughing at Rinieri.

Rinieri, freezing and realizing he was tricked, felt his love turn to bitter hatred. He resolved to seek revenge. He feigned continued love. Some time later, Elena's lover abandoned her for another woman, leaving her distraught. Her maid, thinking Rinieri could use necromancy to bring the lover back, suggested she seek his help. Elena, desperate, agreed. Rinieri, overjoyed at the chance for revenge, agreed to help. He instructed Elena to bathe naked seven times in a running stream at midnight during the waning moon, then climb an uninhabited tower, face north, and recite a conjuration with a pewter image.

Elena, eager, went to her farm by the Arno. Rinieri, hidden nearby, watched her bathe and climb the tower. He felt a moment of pity and temptation but, remembering his past suffering, remained resolute. He then quietly removed the ladder from the tower. Elena, after reciting the conjuration, waited for the two damsels she expected. As dawn broke, she realized she had been tricked. She tried to descend but found the ladder gone. She fainted, then, recovering, wept, blaming herself and the scholar.

The sun rose, scorching her naked body. Flies and gadflies stung her. She suffered from hunger, thirst, and the heat. She was disfigured. She called for help, but no one was around. Rinieri, after sleeping, returned to the tower. Elena begged him for water or death. Rinieri, enjoying her torment, refused, reminding her of the cold he suffered. He mocked her beauty, saying it would be marred. He claimed his revenge was just, and that his pen could have inflicted worse shame. He told her to cast herself down if she wished to die.

Elena continued to plead. Finally, Rinieri, after much delay, agreed to help, for the sake of the new lady he claimed to love. He asked where her clothes were. She told him. He went to his friend's house for dinner and a nap, leaving his servant to guard the tower. Elena, alone and despairing, fell asleep. The sun continued to burn her. A husbandman, searching for lost swine, found her. He helped her down and carried her to his house. Her maid, rushing to the tower, fell from the ladder and broke her thigh. Elena and her maid were taken to Florence. Elena, using her wit, fabricated a story of diabolical bewitchments to explain their injuries. She recovered, renounced love, and avoided mocking others. Rinieri, hearing of the maid's broken thigh, felt his revenge complete.

**Story 8: Two Men Consorting Together (Fiammetta)**
Fiammetta tells of Spinelloccio Tanena and Zeppa di Mino, two close friends and neighbors in Siena, both with beautiful wives. Spinelloccio began an affair with Zeppa's wife. One day, Zeppa, at home unexpectedly, saw his wife and Spinelloccio kissing and going into a chamber. Zeppa, enraged, hid, resolving to take revenge without public scandal.

After Spinelloccio left, Zeppa confronted his wife, who confessed. Zeppa, to forgive her, demanded she help him trick Spinelloccio. She was to invite Spinelloccio to her house the next morning. When Zeppa returned, she was to hide Spinelloccio in a chest. The next morning, Spinelloccio, having promised to meet Zeppa's wife, made an excuse to leave Zeppa. He went to Zeppa's house and entered the chamber with Zeppa's wife. When Zeppa returned, she quickly locked Spinelloccio in the chest.

Zeppa then asked his wife to invite Spinelloccio's wife to dine, as Spinelloccio was supposedly dining elsewhere. Spinelloccio's wife came. Zeppa, taking her hand, led her to the chamber, locked the door, and revealed he knew of her husband's affair with his wife. He declared his revenge: he would lie with her on the chest where her husband was hidden. He then made love to Spinelloccio's wife on the chest. Spinelloccio, trapped inside, heard and felt everything. He was initially furious but realized he had initiated the offense and Zeppa was acting humanely. He resolved to remain friends.

After they finished, Zeppa's wife, asking for a promised jewel, was shown her husband in the chest. Spinelloccio emerged, and, acknowledging they were "quits," proposed they remain friends and share their wives. Zeppa agreed. All four dined together in harmony. From then on, each lady had two husbands, and each man two wives, without strife.

**Story 9: Master Simone the Physician (Elisa)**
Elisa tells of Master Simone da Villa, a physician from Bologna, rich but ignorant, who returned to Florence dressed ostentatiously. He was curious about Bruno and Buffalmacco, two poor but merry painters, believing they had a secret source of wealth. He befriended Bruno, who, realizing Simone's foolishness, decided to play a trick. Bruno claimed he and Buffalmacco were part of a secret company that "went a-roving," acquiring wealth and pleasures (including beautiful women like the Queen of England and the Empress of Tartary) through magical means, without stealing. He described lavish banquets and beautiful women. He warned Simone to keep it secret.

Simone, believing this fantastical tale, was desperate to join. He plied Bruno with hospitality. Bruno, in return, painted a picture of Lent in Simone's saloon and an Agnus Dei by his chamber, along with a chamber-pot over the street door. Bruno continued to tease Simone with stories of their "roving" adventures. Simone, eager to join, finally confessed his desire to Bruno, boasting of his own noble birth, wealth, learning, and ability to attract women. Bruno, barely containing his laughter, feigned reluctance but eventually agreed to help, on condition of secrecy. He told Simone that Buffalmacco would soon be captain of the company and could admit him. Simone was to befriend and honor Buffalmacco.

Simone lavished hospitality on both painters. When he felt the time was right, he asked Buffalmacco to admit him. Buffalmacco feigned anger at Bruno for revealing the secret but was "pacified" by Simone's apologies. Buffalmacco then "praised" Simone's wit, calling him a "seed-pumpkin" and saying he was "baptized on a Sunday" (meaning simple). He promised to admit Simone. They then described the "Countess of Jakes" (public sewers) as a grand lady whom Simone would meet.

The painters instructed Simone to go to a raised tomb outside Santa Maria Novella at the first sleep, dressed in his finest scarlet gown. A "black horned beast" would come, caper, and whistle to terrify him. If he showed no fear, he was to mount the beast, cross his hands, and name neither God nor saints. The beast would take him to the company. If he showed fear, he might be thrown into a "place where you are like to stink for it." Simone, confident in his courage, agreed.

That night, Simone, in his scarlet gown, waited on a tomb. Buffalmacco, disguised as a horned bear, raged about the piazza. Simone, terrified, eventually mounted the "beast." Buffalmacco carried him to the dykes near the Nunnery of Ripole, which were filled with ordure. He then pitched Simone headfirst into the filth. Buffalmacco and Bruno, who had been watching, laughed. Simone struggled out, covered in excrement, and returned home. His wife, disgusted, scolded him for his philandering.

The next morning, Bruno and Buffalmacco, having painted themselves with bruises, confronted Simone, accusing him of disloyalty and causing them to be beaten. Simone tried to explain, but they refused to listen, saying he had called on God and the saints, breaking the rules. Simone, terrified of public exposure, appeased them with more hospitality. Thus, Simone, the "sheepshead" from Bologna, learned a lesson.

**Story 10: A Certain Woman of Sicily (Dioneo)**
Dioneo tells of a custom in Palermo where merchants' goods are stored in a customhouse, and their details recorded. Many beautiful but dishonest women, posing as noble ladies, used this information to lure merchants into affairs and rob them. Salabaetto, a Florentine merchant, arrived in Palermo with woollen cloths worth 500 gold florins. He displayed his wealth and was noticed by Madam Biancofiore, one of these "barberesses." She sent her maid to him, feigning love and arranging a secret meeting at a bagnio.

Salabaetto, believing her to be a great lady, was overjoyed. At the bagnio, he found a lavish setup. Biancofiore, after embracing him, personally bathed him with musk-scented soap. They were then carried to a bed, sprinkled with sweet waters, and given confections and wine. Salabaetto felt he was in Paradise. After the slave-girls left, he and Biancofiore made love. She then invited him to sup and lie with her at her house. He agreed. At her house, he saw rich furnishings and perfumes, further convincing him of her high status. He spent the night with her, growing more enamored. In the morning, she gave him a silver girdle and purse, pledging her devotion.

Salabaetto sold his cloths at a good profit. Biancofiore, learning of his success, decided to get more from him. One night, she feigned distress, claiming her brother needed 1,000 gold florins within eight days to avoid execution, and she had no way to get it. Salabaetto, blinded by love, offered his 500 florins, which she accepted, promising to repay him in a fortnight.

After she had the money, Biancofiore became distant. When the fortnight passed, then a month or two, she gave him excuses instead of repayment. Salabaetto realized he had been tricked. Ashamed, he left Palermo for Naples, where he confided in his friend Pietro dello Canigiano, a shrewd treasurer. Canigiano advised him to return to Palermo, feigning to have brought even more valuable merchandise.
